dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Sir Hugh, persuade me not. I will make a Star Chamber matter of it. If he were twenty Sir John Falstaffs, he shall not abuse Robert Shallow, esquire.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: In the county of Gloucester, Justice of Peace and Coram.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Ay, cousin Slender, and Custalorum.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Ay, and Ratolorum too; and a gentleman born, Master Parson, who writes himself "Armigero" in any bill, warrant, quittance, or obligation-"Armigero."

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Ay, that I do, and have done any time these three hundred years.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: All his successors, gone before him hath done't; and all his ancestors that come after him may. They may give the dozen white luces in their coat.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: It is an old coat.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: The dozen white louses do become an old coat well. It agrees well, passant. It is a familiar beast to man, and signifies love.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: The luce is the fresh fish. The salt fish is an old coat.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: I may quarter, coz.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: You may, by marrying.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: It is marring indeed, if he quarter it.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Not a whit.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Yes, py'r Lady. If he has a quarter of your coat, there is but three skirts for yourself, in my simple conjectures. But that is all one. If Sir John Falstaff have committed disparagements unto you, I am of the Church, and will be glad to do my benevolence to make atonements and compremises between you.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: The Council shall hear it; it is a riot.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: It is not meet the Council hear a riot. There is no fear of Got in a riot. The Council, look you, shall desire to hear the fear of Got, and not to hear a riot. Take your vizaments in that.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Ha! O' my life, if I were young again, the sword should end it.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: It is petter that friends is the sword, and end it; and there is also another device in my prain, which peradventure prings goot discretions with it. There is Anne Page, which is daughter to Master George Page, which is pretty virginity.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Mistress Anne Page? She has brown hair, and speaks small like a woman?

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: It is that fery person for all the 'orld, as just as you will desire, and seven hundred pounds of moneys, and gold, and silver, is her grandsire upon his death's-bed-Got deliver to a joyful resurrections!-give, when she is able to overtake seventeen years old. It were a goot motion if we leave our pribbles and prabbles, and desire a marriage between Master Abraham and Mistress Anne Page.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Did her grandsire leave her seven hundred pound?

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Ay, and her father is make her a petter penny.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: I know the young gentlewoman; she has good gifts.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Seven hundred pounds, and possibilities, is goot gifts.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Well, let us see honest Master Page. Is Falstaff there?

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Shall I tell you a lie? I do despise a liar as I do despise one that is false, or as I despise one that is not true. The knight Sir John is there, and I beseech you be ruled by your well-willers. I will peat the door for Master Page. What, ho! Got pless your house here!

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Here is Got's plessing, and your friend, and Justice Shallow, and here young Master Slender, that peradventures shall tell you another tale, if matters grow to your likings.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: I am glad to see your worships well. I thank you for my venison, Master Shallow.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Master Page, I am glad to see you, much good do it your good heart! I wished your venison better; it was ill killed. How doth good Mistress Page? And I thank you always with my heart, la, with my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Sir, I thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Sir, I thank you; by yea and no, I do.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: I am glad to see you, good Master Slender.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: How does your fallow greyhound, sir? I heard say he was outrun on Cotsall.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: It could not be judged, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: You'll not confess, you'll not confess.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: That he will not. 'Tis your fault; 'tis your fault. 'Tis a good dog.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: A cur, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Sir, he's a good dog, and a fair dog, can there be more said? He is good, and fair. Is Sir John Falstaff here?

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Sir, he is within; and I would I could do a good office between you.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: It is spoke as a Christians ought to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: He hath wronged me, Master Page.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Sir, he doth in some sort confess it.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: If it be confessed, it is not redressed. Is not that so, Master Page? He hath wronged me, indeed he hath, at a word, he hath. Believe me. Robert Shallow, esquire, saith he is wronged.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Here comes Sir John.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Now, Master Shallow, you'll complain of me to the King?

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Knight, you have beaten my men, killed my deer, and broke open my lodge.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: But not kissed your keeper's daughter!

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Tut, a pin! This shall be answered.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: I will answer it straight: I have done all this. That is now answered.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: The Council shall know this.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: 'Twere better for you if it were known in counsel: you'll be laughed at.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: _Pauca verba_, Sir John; goot worts.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Good worts? Good cabbage!-Slender, I broke your head. What matter have you against me?

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, I have matter in my head against you, and against your cony-catching rascals, Bardolph, Nym, and Pistol. They carried me to the tavern and made me drunk, and afterwards picked my pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Bardolph
dialogues.line: You Banbury cheese!

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Ay, it is no matter.

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: How now, Mephostophilus?

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Ay, it is no matter.

dialogues.speaker: Nym
dialogues.line: Slice, I say! _Pauca, pauca_, slice, that's my humour.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Where's Simple, my man? Can you tell, cousin?

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Peace, I pray you. Now let us understand; there is three umpires in this matter, as I understand: that is, Master Page, _fidelicet_ Master Page; and there is myself, _fidelicet_ myself; and the three party is, lastly and finally, mine host of the Garter.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: We three to hear it and end it between them.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Fery goot. I will make a prief of it in my notebook, and we will afterwards 'ork upon the cause with as great discreetly as we can.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Pistol!

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: He hears with ears.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: The tevil and his tam! What phrase is this, "He hears with ear"? Why, it is affectations.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Pistol, did you pick Master Slender's purse?

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Ay, by these gloves, did he, or I would I might never come in mine own great chamber again else! Of seven groats in mill-sixpences, and two Edward shovel-boards that cost me two shilling and two pence a-piece of Yed Miller, by these gloves.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Is this true, Pistol?

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: No, it is false, if it is a pick-purse.

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: Ha, thou mountain-foreigner!-Sir John and master mine, I combat challenge of this latten bilbo.- Word of denial in thy _labras_ here! Word of denial! Froth and scum, thou liest.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: By these gloves, then, 'twas he.

dialogues.speaker: Nym
dialogues.line: Be avised, sir, and pass good humours. I will say "marry trap with you", if you run the nuthook's humour on me. That is the very note of it.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: By this hat, then, he in the red face had it. For though I cannot remember what I did when you made me drunk, yet I am not altogether an ass.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: What say you, Scarlet and John?

dialogues.speaker: Bardolph
dialogues.line: Why, sir, for my part, I say the gentleman had drunk himself out of his five sentences.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: It is his "five senses". Fie, what the ignorance is!

dialogues.speaker: Bardolph
dialogues.line: And being fap, sir, was, as they say, cashiered; and so conclusions passed the careers.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Ay, you spake in Latin then too; but 'tis no matter. I'll ne'er be drunk whilst I live again, but in honest, civil, godly company, for this trick. If I be drunk, I'll be drunk with those that have the fear of God, and not with drunken knaves.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: So Got 'udge me, that is a virtuous mind.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: You hear all these matters denied, gentlemen; you hear it. wine.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Nay, daughter, carry the wine in, we'll drink within.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: O heaven, this is Mistress Anne Page.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: How now, Mistress Ford?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Mistress Ford, by my troth, you are very well met. By your leave, good mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Wife, bid these gentlemen welcome. Come, we have a hot venison pasty to dinner. Come, gentlemen, I hope we shall drink down all unkindness.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: I had rather than forty shillings I had my book of _Songs and Sonnets_ here. How now, Simple, where have you been? I must wait on myself, must I? You have not the _Book of Riddles_ about you, have you?

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: _Book of Riddles?_ Why, did you not lend it to Alice Shortcake upon Allhallowmas last, a fortnight afore Michaelmas?

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Come, coz; come, coz, we stay for you. A word with you, coz. Marry, this, coz: there is, as 'twere, a tender, a kind of tender, made afar off by Sir Hugh here. Do you understand me?

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Ay, sir, you shall find me reasonable. If it be so, I shall do that that is reason.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Nay, but understand me.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: So I do, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Give ear to his motions, Master Slender. I will description the matter to you, if you be capacity of it.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Nay, I will do as my cousin Shallow says. I pray you pardon me, he's a Justice of Peace in his country, simple though I stand here.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: But that is not the question. The question is concerning your marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Ay, there's the point, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Marry, is it; the very point of it-to Mistress Anne Page.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Why, if it be so, I will marry her upon any reasonable demands.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: But can you affection the 'oman? Let us command to know that of your mouth, or of your lips; for divers philosophers hold that the lips is parcel of the mouth. Therefore, precisely, can you carry your good will to the maid?

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Cousin Abraham Slender, can you love her?

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: I hope, sir, I will do as it shall become one that would do reason.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Nay, Got's lords and his ladies! You must speak possitable, if you can carry her your desires towards her.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: That you must. Will you, upon good dowry, marry her?

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: I will do a greater thing than that, upon your request, cousin, in any reason.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Nay, conceive me, conceive me, sweet coz. What I do is to pleasure you, coz. Can you love the maid?

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: I will marry her, sir, at your request. But if there be no great love in the beginning, yet heaven may decrease it upon better acquaintance, when we are married and have more occasion to know one another. I hope upon familiarity will grow more contempt. But if you say "Marry her," I will marry her. That I am freely dissolved, and dissolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: It is a fery discretion answer, save the fall is in the 'ord "dissolutely." The 'ort is, according to our meaning, "resolutely." His meaning is good.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Ay, I think my cousin meant well.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Ay, or else I would I might be hanged, la!

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Here comes fair Mistress Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Here comes fair Mistress Anne.-Would I were young for your sake, Mistress Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: The dinner is on the table, my father desires your worships' company.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: I will wait on him, fair Mistress Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: 'Od's plessed will! I will not be absence at the grace.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Will't please your worship to come in, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: No, I thank you, forsooth, heartily; I am very well.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: The dinner attends you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: I am not a-hungry, I thank you, forsooth.  Go, sirrah, for all you are my man, go wait upon my cousin Shallow. A Justice of Peace sometime may be beholding to his friend for a man. I keep but three men and a boy yet, till my mother be dead. But what though? Yet I live like a poor gentleman born.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: I may not go in without your worship. They will not sit till you come.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: I' faith, I'll eat nothing. I thank you as much as though I did.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: I pray you, sir, walk in.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: I had rather walk here, I thank you. I bruised my shin th' other day with playing at sword and dagger with a master of fence-three veneys for a dish of stewed prunes-and, by my troth, I cannot abide the smell of hot meat since. Why do your dogs bark so? Be there bears i' the town?

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: I think there are, sir; I heard them talked of.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: I love the sport well, but I shall as soon quarrel at it as any man in England. You are afraid, if you see the bear loose, are you not?

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Ay, indeed, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: That's meat and drink to me now. I have seen Sackerson loose twenty times, and have taken him by the chain. But, I warrant you, the women have so cried and shrieked at it that it passed. But women, indeed, cannot abide 'em; they are very ill-favoured rough things.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Come, gentle Master Slender, come. We stay for you.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: I'll eat nothing, I thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: By cock and pie, you shall not choose, sir! Come, come.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Nay, pray you lead the way.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Come on, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Mistress Anne, yourself shall go first.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Not I, sir; pray you keep on.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Truly, I will not go first; truly, la! I will not do you that wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: I pray you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: I'll rather be unmannerly than troublesome. You do yourself wrong, indeed, la!

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Go your ways, and ask of Doctor Caius' house which is the way. And there dwells one Mistress Quickly, which is in the manner of his nurse, or his dry nurse, or his cook, or his laundry, his washer and his wringer.

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: Well, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Nay, it is petter yet. Give her this letter. For it is a 'oman that altogether's acquaintance with Mistress Anne Page; and the letter is to desire and require her to solicit your master's desires to Mistress Anne Page. I pray you be gone. I will make an end of my dinner; there's pippins and cheese to come.

scenes.location: A room in the Garter Inn

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Mine host of the Garter!

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: What says my bully rook? Speak scholarly and wisely.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Truly, mine host, I must turn away some of my followers.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Discard, bully Hercules; cashier. Let them wag; trot, trot.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: I sit at ten pounds a week.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Thou'rt an emperor-Caesar, Keiser, and Pheazar. I will entertain Bardolph. He shall draw, he shall tap. Said I well, bully Hector?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Do so, good mine host.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: I have spoke, let him follow.-Let me see thee froth and lime. I am at a word, follow.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Bardolph, follow him. A tapster is a good trade. An old cloak makes a new jerkin; a withered servingman a fresh tapster. Go, adieu.

dialogues.speaker: Bardolph
dialogues.line: It is a life that I have desired. I will thrive.

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: O base Hungarian wight, wilt thou the spigot wield?

dialogues.speaker: Nym
dialogues.line: He was gotten in drink. Is not the humour conceited?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: I am glad I am so acquit of this tinderbox. His thefts were too open. His filching was like an unskilful singer, he kept not time.

dialogues.speaker: Nym
dialogues.line: The good humour is to steal at a minute's rest.

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: "Convey," the wise it call. "Steal?" Foh! A _fico_ for the phrase!

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Well, sirs, I am almost out at heels.

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: Why, then, let kibes ensue.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: There is no remedy, I must cony-catch, I must shift.

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: Young ravens must have food.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Which of you know Ford of this town?

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: I ken the wight, he is of substance good.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: My honest lads, I will tell you what I am about.

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: Two yards, and more.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: No quips now, Pistol. Indeed, I am in the waist two yards about, but I am now about no waste; I am about thrift. Briefly, I do mean to make love to Ford's wife. I spy entertainment in her. She discourses, she carves, she gives the leer of invitation. I can construe the action of her familiar style; and the hardest voice of her behaviour, to be Englished rightly, is "I am Sir John Falstaff's."

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: He hath studied her will and translated her will-out of honesty into English.

dialogues.speaker: Nym
dialogues.line: The anchor is deep. Will that humour pass?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Now, the report goes she has all the rule of her husband's purse. He hath a legion of angels.

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: As many devils entertain, and "To her, boy," say I.

dialogues.speaker: Nym
dialogues.line: The humour rises; it is good. Humour me the angels.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: I have writ me here a letter to her; and here another to Page's wife, who even now gave me good eyes too, examined my parts with most judicious oeillades. Sometimes the beam of her view gilded my foot, sometimes my portly belly.

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: Then did the sun on dunghill shine.

dialogues.speaker: Nym
dialogues.line: I thank thee for that humour.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: O, she did so course o'er my exteriors with such a greedy intention that the appetite of her eye did seem to scorch me up like a burning-glass. Here's another letter to her. She bears the purse too; she is a region in Guiana, all gold and bounty. I will be cheaters to them both, and they shall be exchequers to me; they shall be my East and West Indies, and I will trade to them both. Go, bear thou this letter to Mistress Page;-and thou this to Mistress Ford. We will thrive, lads, we will thrive.

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: Shall I Sir Pandarus of Troy become, And by my side wear steel? Then Lucifer take all!

dialogues.speaker: Nym
dialogues.line: I will run no base humour. Here, take the humour-letter. I will keep the 'haviour of reputation.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Hold, sirrah, bear you these letters tightly; Sail like my pinnace to these golden shores.- Rogues, hence, avaunt! Vanish like hailstones, go! Trudge, plod away o' th' hoof, seek shelter, pack! Falstaff will learn the humour of this age: French thrift, you rogues-myself and skirted page.

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: Let vultures gripe thy guts! For gourd and fullam holds, And high and low beguile the rich and poor. Tester I'll have in pouch when thou shalt lack, Base Phrygian Turk!

dialogues.speaker: Nym
dialogues.line: I have operations in my head which be humours of revenge.

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: Wilt thou revenge?

dialogues.speaker: Nym
dialogues.line: By welkin and her star!

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: With wit or steel?

dialogues.speaker: Nym
dialogues.line: With both the humours, I. I will discuss the humour of this love to Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: And I to Page shall eke unfold How Falstaff, varlet vile, His dove will prove, his gold will hold, And his soft couch defile.

dialogues.speaker: Nym
dialogues.line: My humour shall not cool. I will incense Ford to deal with poison, I will possess him with yellowness, for the revolt of mine is dangerous. That is my true humour.

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: Thou art the Mars of malcontents. I second thee. Troop on.

scenes.location: A room in Doctor Caius's house

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: What, John Rugby! I pray thee go to the casement, and see if you can see my master, Master Doctor Caius, coming. If he do, i' faith, and find anybody in the house, here will be an old abusing of God's patience and the King's English.

dialogues.speaker: Rugby
dialogues.line: I'll go watch.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Go; and we'll have a posset for't soon at night, in faith, at the latter end of a sea-coal fire. An honest, willing, kind fellow, as ever servant shall come in house withal; and, I warrant you, no tell-tale nor no breed-bate. His worst fault is that he is given to prayer; he is something peevish that way, but nobody but has his fault. But let that pass. Peter Simple you say your name is?

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: Ay, for fault of a better.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: And Master Slender's your master?

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: Ay, forsooth.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Does he not wear a great round beard, like a glover's paring-knife?

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: No, forsooth, he hath but a little wee face, with a little yellow beard, a Cain-coloured beard.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: A softly-sprighted man, is he not?

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: Ay, forsooth. But he is as tall a man of his hands as any is between this and his head. He hath fought with a warrener.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: How say you? O, I should remember him. Does he not hold up his head, as it were, and strut in his gait?

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: Yes, indeed, does he.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Well, heaven send Anne Page no worse fortune! Tell Master Parson Evans I will do what I can for your master. Anne is a good girl, and I wish-

dialogues.speaker: Rugby
dialogues.line: Out, alas! Here comes my master.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: We shall all be shent. Run in here, good young man, go into this closet. He will not stay long. What, John Rugby! John! What, John, I say! Go, John, go inquire for my master. I doubt he be not well, that he comes not home.  _And down, down, adown-a, etc._

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Vat is you sing? I do not like dese toys. Pray you, go and vetch me in my closet _une boîtine verte_, a box, a green-a box. Do intend vat I speak? A green-a box.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Ay, forsooth, I'll fetch it you.  I am glad he went not in himself. If he had found the young man, he would have been horn-mad.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: _Fe, fe, fe fe! Ma foi, il fait fort chaud. Je m'en vais à la cour-la grande affaire._

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Is it this, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: _Oui, mette-le au mon_ pocket. _Dépêche_, quickly-Vere is dat knave Rugby?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: What, John Rugby, John!

dialogues.speaker: Rugby
dialogues.line: Here, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: You are John Rugby, and you are Jack Rugby. Come, take-a your rapier, and come after my heel to the court.

dialogues.speaker: Rugby
dialogues.line: 'Tis ready, sir, here in the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: By my trot, I tarry too long. 'Od's me! _Qu'ay j'oublié?_ Dere is some simples in my closet dat I vill not for the varld I shall leave behind.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Ay me, he'll find the young man there, and be mad!

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: _O diable, diable!_ Vat is in my closet? Villainy! _Larron!_  Rugby, my rapier!

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Good master, be content.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Wherefore shall I be content-a?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: The young man is an honest man.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: What shall de honest man do in my closet? Dere is no honest man dat shall come in my closet.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: I beseech you, be not so phlegmatic. Hear the truth of it. He came of an errand to me from Parson Hugh.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Vell?

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: Ay, forsooth, to desire her to-

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Peace, I pray you.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Peace-a your tongue!-Speak-a your tale.

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: To desire this honest gentlewoman, your maid, to speak a good word to Mistress Anne Page for my master in the way of marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: This is all, indeed, la! But I'll ne'er put my finger in the fire, and need not.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Sir Hugh send-a you?-Rugby, _baille_ me some paper.-Tarry you a little-a while.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: I am glad he is so quiet. If he had been throughly moved, you should have heard him so loud and so melancholy. But notwithstanding, man, I'll do you your master what good I can; and the very yea and the no is, the French doctor, my master-I may call him my master, look you, for I keep his house, and I wash, wring, brew, bake, scour, dress meat and drink, make the beds, and do all myself-

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: 'Tis a great charge to come under one body's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Are you avised o' that? You shall find it a great charge, and to be up early and down late; but notwithstanding-to tell you in your ear, I would have no words of it-my master himself is in love with Mistress Anne Page; but notwithstanding that, I know Anne's mind. That's neither here nor there.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: You jack'nape, give-a dis letter to Sir Hugh. By gar, it is a shallenge. I will cut his troat in de park, and I will teach a scurvy jackanape priest to meddle or make. You may be gone, it is not good you tarry here.-By gar, I will cut all his two stones. By gar, he shall not have a stone to throw at his dog.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Alas, he speaks but for his friend.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: It is no matter-a ver dat. Do not you tell-a me dat I shall have Anne Page for myself? By gar, I vill kill de Jack priest; and I have appointed mine host of de Jarteer to measure our weapon. By gar, I will myself have Anne Page.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Sir, the maid loves you, and all shall be well. We must give folks leave to prate. What, the good-year!

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Rugby, come to the court with me.  By gar, if I have not Anne Page, I shall turn your head out of my door.-Follow my heels, Rugby.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: You shall have An-fool's head of your own. No, I know Anne's mind for that. Never a woman in Windsor knows more of Anne's mind than I do, nor can do more than I do with her, I thank heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Fenton
dialogues.line: Who's within there, ho?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Who's there, I trow? Come near the house, I pray you.

dialogues.speaker: Fenton
dialogues.line: How now, good woman? How dost thou?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: The better, that it pleases your good worship to ask.

dialogues.speaker: Fenton
dialogues.line: What news? How does pretty Mistress Anne?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: In truth, sir, and she is pretty, and honest, and gentle; and one that is your friend, I can tell you that by the way, I praise heaven for it.

dialogues.speaker: Fenton
dialogues.line: Shall I do any good, think'st thou? Shall I not lose my suit?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Troth, sir, all is in His hands above. But notwithstanding, Master Fenton, I'll be sworn on a book she loves you. Have not your worship a wart above your eye?

dialogues.speaker: Fenton
dialogues.line: Yes, marry, have I; what of that?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Well, thereby hangs a tale. Good faith, it is such another Nan! But, I detest, an honest maid as ever broke bread. We had an hour's talk of that wart. I shall never laugh but in that maid's company. But, indeed, she is given too much to allicholy and musing. But for you-well, go to.

dialogues.speaker: Fenton
dialogues.line: Well, I shall see her today. Hold, there's money for thee. Let me have thy voice in my behalf. If thou seest her before me, commend me.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Will I? I' faith, that we will! And I will tell your worship more of the wart the next time we have confidence, and of other wooers.

dialogues.speaker: Fenton
dialogues.line: Well, farewell, I am in great haste now.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Farewell to your worship. Truly, an honest gentleman-but Anne loves him not, for I know Anne's mind as well as another does. Out upon 't, what have I forgot?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: What, have I scaped love-letters in the holiday-time of my beauty, and am I now a subject for them? Let me see.  _Ask me no reason why I love you, for though Love use Reason for his precisian, he admits him not for his counsellor. You are not young, no more am I. Go to, then, there's sympathy. You are merry, so am I. Ha, ha, then there's more sympathy. You love sack, and so do I. Would you desire better sympathy? Let it suffice thee, Mistress Page, at the least, if the love of soldier can suffice, that I love thee. I will not say, pity me-'tis not a soldier-like phrase-but I say love me. By me, Thine own true knight, By day or night, Or any kind of light, With all his might, For thee to fight, John Falstaff._ What a Herod of Jewry is this! O wicked, wicked world! One that is well-nigh worn to pieces with age, to show himself a young gallant! What an unweighed behaviour hath this Flemish drunkard picked-with the devil's name!-out of my conversation, that he dares in this manner assay me? Why, he hath not been thrice in my company! What should I say to him? I was then frugal of my mirth. Heaven forgive me! Why, I'll exhibit a bill in the parliament for the putting down of men. How shall I be revenged on him? For revenged I will be, as sure as his guts are made of puddings.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Mistress Page! Trust me, I was going to your house.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: And, trust me, I was coming to you. You look very ill.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Nay, I'll ne'er believe that. I have to show to the contrary.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Faith, but you do, in my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Well, I do, then. Yet I say I could show you to the contrary. O, Mistress Page, give me some counsel.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: What's the matter, woman?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: O woman, if it were not for one trifling respect, I could come to such honour!

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Hang the trifle, woman; take the honour. What is it? Dispense with trifles. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: If I would but go to hell for an eternal moment or so, I could be knighted.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: What? Thou liest! Sir Alice Ford! These knights will hack, and so thou shouldst not alter the article of thy gentry.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: We burn daylight. Here, read, read. Perceive how I might be knighted. I shall think the worse of fat men as long as I have an eye to make difference of men's liking. And yet he would not swear; praised women's modesty; and gave such orderly and well-behaved reproof to all uncomeliness that I would have sworn his disposition would have gone to the truth of his words. But they do no more adhere and keep place together than the Hundredth Psalm to the tune of "Greensleeves." What tempest, I trow, threw this whale, with so many tuns of oil in his belly, ashore at Windsor? How shall I be revenged on him? I think the best way were to entertain him with hope, till the wicked fire of lust have melted him in his own grease. Did you ever hear the like?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Letter for letter, but that the name of Page and Ford differs! To thy great comfort in this mystery of ill opinions, here's the twin brother of thy letter. But let thine inherit first, for I protest mine never shall. I warrant he hath a thousand of these letters, writ with blank space for different names-sure, more, and these are of the second edition. He will print them, out of doubt; for he cares not what he puts into the press, when he would put us two. I had rather be a giantess and lie under Mount Pelion. Well, I will find you twenty lascivious turtles ere one chaste man.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Why, this is the very same-the very hand, the very words. What doth he think of us?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Nay, I know not. It makes me almost ready to wrangle with mine own honesty. I'll entertain myself like one that I am not acquainted withal; for, sure, unless he know some strain in me that I know not myself, he would never have boarded me in this fury.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: "Boarding" call you it? I'll be sure to keep him above deck.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: So will I. If he come under my hatches, I'll never to sea again. Let's be revenged on him. Let's appoint him a meeting, give him a show of comfort in his suit, and lead him on with a fine-baited delay, till he hath pawned his horses to mine host of the Garter.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Nay, I will consent to act any villainy against him that may not sully the chariness of our honesty. O, that my husband saw this letter! It would give eternal food to his jealousy.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Why, look where he comes; and my good man too. He's as far from jealousy as I am from giving him cause, and that, I hope, is an unmeasurable distance.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: You are the happier woman.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Let's consult together against this greasy knight. Come hither.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Well, I hope it be not so.

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: Hope is a curtal dog in some affairs. Sir John affects thy wife.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Why, sir, my wife is not young.

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: He woos both high and low, both rich and poor, Both young and old, one with another, Ford. He loves the gallimaufry. Ford, perpend.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Love my wife?

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: With liver burning hot. Prevent, or go thou like Sir Actaeon he, With Ringwood at thy heels. O, odious is the name!

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: What name, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: The horn, I say. Farewell. Take heed, have open eye, for thieves do foot by night. Take heed, ere summer comes, or cuckoo birds do sing.- Away, Sir Corporal Nym.-Believe it, Page, he speaks sense.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: I will be patient. I will find out this.

dialogues.speaker: Nym
dialogues.line: And this is true, I like not the humour of lying. He hath wronged me in some humours. I should have borne the humoured letter to her; but I have a sword, and it shall bite upon my necessity. He loves your wife; there's the short and the long. My name is Corporal Nym. I speak, and I avouch 'tis true. My name is Nym, and Falstaff loves your wife. Adieu. I love not the humour of bread and cheese. Adieu.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: "The humour of it," quoth 'a! Here's a fellow frights English out of his wits.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: I will seek out Falstaff.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: I never heard such a drawling, affecting rogue.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: If I do find it-well.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: I will not believe such a Cataian, though the priest o' the town commended him for a true man.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: 'Twas a good sensible fellow-well. Mistress Page and Mistress Ford come forward.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: How now, Meg?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Whither go you, George? Hark you.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: How now, sweet Frank, why art thou melancholy?

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: I melancholy? I am not melancholy. Get you home, go.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Faith, thou hast some crotchets in thy head now.-Will you go, Mistress Page?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Have with you. You'll come to dinner, George?  Look who comes yonder. She shall be our messenger to this paltry knight.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Trust me, I thought on her. She'll fit it.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: You are come to see my daughter Anne?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Ay, forsooth. And, I pray, how does good Mistress Anne?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Go in with us and see. We'd have an hour's talk with you.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: How now, Master Ford?

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: You heard what this knave told me, did you not?

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Yes, and you heard what the other told me?

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Do you think there is truth in them?

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Hang 'em, slaves! I do not think the knight would offer it, but these that accuse him in his intent towards our wives are a yoke of his discarded men, very rogues, now they be out of service.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Were they his men?

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Marry, were they.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: I like it never the better for that. Does he lie at the Garter?

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Ay, marry, does he. If he should intend this voyage toward my wife, I would turn her loose to him; and what he gets more of her than sharp words, let it lie on my head.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: I do not misdoubt my wife, but I would be loath to turn them together. A man may be too confident. I would have nothing lie on my head. I cannot be thus satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Look where my ranting host of the Garter comes. There is either liquor in his pate or money in his purse when he looks so merrily.-How now, mine host?

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: How now, bully rook? Thou'rt a gentleman.-Cavaliero Justice, I say!

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: I follow, mine host, I follow.-Good even and twenty, good Master Page. Master Page, will you go with us? We have sport in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Tell him, Cavaliero Justice; tell him, bully rook.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Sir, there is a fray to be fought between Sir Hugh the Welsh priest and Caius the French doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Good mine host o' the Garter, a word with you.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: What say'st thou, my bully rook?

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Will you go with us to behold it? My merry host hath had the measuring of their weapons, and, I think, hath appointed them contrary places; for, believe me, I hear the parson is no jester. Hark, I will tell you what our sport shall be.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Hast thou no suit against my knight, my guest cavaliero?

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: None, I protest. But I'll give you a pottle of burnt sack to give me recourse to him, and tell him my name is Brook, only for a jest.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: My hand, bully. Thou shalt have egress and regress-said I well?-and thy name shall be Brook. It is a merry knight. Will you go, myn-heers?

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Have with you, mine host.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: I have heard the Frenchman hath good skill in his rapier.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Tut, sir, I could have told you more. In these times you stand on distance-your passes, stoccadoes, and I know not what. 'Tis the heart, Master Page; 'tis here, 'tis here. I have seen the time, with my long sword I would have made you four tall fellows skip like rats.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Here, boys, here, here! Shall we wag?

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Have with you. I had rather hear them scold than fight.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Though Page be a secure fool, and stands so firmly on his wife's frailty, yet I cannot put off my opinion so easily. She was in his company at Page's house, and what they made there I know not. Well, I will look further into 't, and I have a disguise to sound Falstaff. If I find her honest, I lose not my labour. If she be otherwise, 'tis labour well bestowed.

scenes.location: A room in the Garter Inn

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: I will not lend thee a penny.

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: Why then, the world's mine oyster, Which I with sword will open.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Not a penny. I have been content, sir, you should lay my countenance to pawn; I have grated upon my good friends for three reprieves for you and your coach-fellow Nym, or else you had looked through the grate like a gemini of baboons. I am damned in hell for swearing to gentlemen my friends you were good soldiers and tall fellows. And when Mistress Bridget lost the handle of her fan, I took 't upon mine honour thou hadst it not.

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: Didst not thou share? Hadst thou not fifteen pence?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Reason, you rogue, reason. Think'st thou I'll endanger my soul gratis? At a word, hang no more about me, I am no gibbet for you. Go-a short knife and a throng-to your manor of Pickt-hatch, go. You'll not bear a letter for me, you rogue? You stand upon your honour! Why, thou unconfinable baseness, it is as much as I can do to keep the terms of my honour precise. Ay, ay, I myself sometimes, leaving the fear of God on the left hand, and hiding mine honour in my necessity, am fain to shuffle, to hedge, and to lurch; and yet you, rogue, will ensconce your rags, your cat-a-mountain looks, your red-lattice phrases, and your bold beating oaths, under the shelter of your honour! You will not do it! You!

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: I do relent. What wouldst thou more of man?

dialogues.speaker: Robin
dialogues.line: Sir, here's a woman would speak with you.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Let her approach.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Give your worship good morrow.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Good morrow, goodwife.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Not so, an't please your worship.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Good maid, then.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: I'll be sworn, as my mother was, the first hour I was born.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: I do believe the swearer. What with me?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Shall I vouchsafe your worship a word or two?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Two thousand, fair woman; and I'll vouchsafe thee the hearing.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: There is one Mistress Ford, sir-I pray, come a little nearer this ways. I myself dwell with Master Doctor Caius.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Well, on; Mistress Ford, you say-

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Your worship says very true. I pray your worship come a little nearer this ways.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: I warrant thee, nobody hears. Mine own people, mine own people.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Are they so? God bless them, and make them His servants!

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Well, Mistress Ford, what of her?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Why, sir, she's a good creature. Lord, Lord, your worship's a wanton! Well, heaven forgive you, and all of us, I pray!

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Mistress Ford, come, Mistress Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Marry, this is the short and the long of it: you have brought her into such a canaries as 'tis wonderful. The best courtier of them all, when the court lay at Windsor, could never have brought her to such a canary. Yet there has been knights, and lords, and gentlemen, with their coaches, I warrant you, coach after coach, letter after letter, gift after gift, smelling so sweetly, all musk, and so rushling, I warrant you, in silk and gold, and in such alligant terms, and in such wine and sugar of the best and the fairest, that would have won any woman's heart; and I warrant you, they could never get an eye-wink of her. I had myself twenty angels given me this morning, but I defy all angels in any such sort, as they say, but in the way of honesty. And, I warrant you, they could never get her so much as sip on a cup with the proudest of them all. And yet there has been earls-nay, which is more, pensioners-but, I warrant you, all is one with her.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: But what says she to me? Be brief, my good she-Mercury.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Marry, she hath received your letter, for the which she thanks you a thousand times; and she gives you to notify that her husband will be absence from his house between ten and eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Ten and eleven?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Ay, forsooth; and then you may come and see the picture, she says, that you wot of. Master Ford, her husband, will be from home. Alas, the sweet woman leads an ill life with him. He's a very jealousy man; she leads a very frampold life with him, good heart.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Ten and eleven. Woman, commend me to her; I will not fail her.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Why, you say well. But I have another messenger to your worship. Mistress Page hath her hearty commendations to you too; and let me tell you in your ear, she's as fartuous a civil modest wife, and one, I tell you, that will not miss you morning nor evening prayer, as any is in Windsor, whoe'er be the other; and she bade me tell your worship that her husband is seldom from home, but she hopes there will come a time. I never knew a woman so dote upon a man. Surely I think you have charms, la! Yes, in truth.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Not I, I assure thee. Setting the attraction of my good parts aside, I have no other charms.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Blessing on your heart for 't!

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: But, I pray thee, tell me this: has Ford's wife and Page's wife acquainted each other how they love me?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: That were a jest indeed! They have not so little grace, I hope. That were a trick indeed! But Mistress Page would desire you to send her your little page, of all loves. Her husband has a marvellous infection to the little page; and, truly, Master Page is an honest man. Never a wife in Windsor leads a better life than she does. Do what she will, say what she will, take all, pay all, go to bed when she list, rise when she list, all is as she will, and truly she deserves it, for if there be a kind woman in Windsor, she is one. You must send her your page, no remedy.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Why, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Nay, but do so then, and, look you, he may come and go between you both; and in any case have a nay-word, that you may know one another's mind, and the boy never need to understand anything; for 'tis not good that children should know any wickedness. Old folks, you know, have discretion, as they say, and know the world.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Fare thee well, commend me to them both. There's my purse; I am yet thy debtor. Boy, go along with this woman.-This news distracts me.

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: This punk is one of Cupid's carriers; Clap on more sails, pursue; up with your fights; Give fire! She is my prize, or ocean whelm them all!

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Sayst thou so, old Jack? Go thy ways, I'll make more of thy old body than I have done. Will they yet look after thee? Wilt thou, after the expense of so much money, be now a gainer? Good body, I thank thee. Let them say 'tis grossly done; so it be fairly done, no matter.

dialogues.speaker: Bardolph
dialogues.line: Sir John, there's one Master Brook below would fain speak with you and be acquainted with you, and hath sent your worship a morning's draught of sack.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Brook is his name?

dialogues.speaker: Bardolph
dialogues.line: Ay, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Call him in. Such Brooks are welcome to me, that o'erflow such liquor. Ah, ha, Mistress Ford and Mistress Page, have I encompassed you? Go to, _via!_

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: God bless you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: And you, sir. Would you speak with me?

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: I make bold to press with so little preparation upon you.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: You're welcome. What's your will?-Give us leave, drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Sir, I am a gentleman that have spent much. My name is Brook.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Good Master Brook, I desire more acquaintance of you.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Good Sir John, I sue for yours; not to charge you, for I must let you understand I think myself in better plight for a lender than you are, the which hath something emboldened me to this unseasoned intrusion; for they say, if money go before, all ways do lie open.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Money is a good soldier, sir, and will on.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Troth, and I have a bag of money here troubles me. If you will help to bear it, Sir John, take all, or half, for easing me of the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Sir, I know not how I may deserve to be your porter.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: I will tell you, sir, if you will give me the hearing.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Speak, good Master Brook. I shall be glad to be your servant.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Sir, I hear you are a scholar-I will be brief with you-and you have been a man long known to me, though I had never so good means as desire to make myself acquainted with you. I shall discover a thing to you, wherein I must very much lay open mine own imperfection. But, good Sir John, as you have one eye upon my follies, as you hear them unfolded, turn another into the register of your own, that I may pass with a reproof the easier, sith you yourself know how easy it is to be such an offender.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Very well, sir, proceed.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: There is a gentlewoman in this town, her husband's name is Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Well, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: I have long loved her, and, I protest to you, bestowed much on her, followed her with a doting observance, engrossed opportunities to meet her, fee'd every slight occasion that could but niggardly give me sight of her, not only bought many presents to give her, but have given largely to many to know what she would have given. Briefly, I have pursued her as love hath pursued me, which hath been on the wing of all occasions. But whatsoever I have merited, either in my mind or in my means, meed, I am sure, I have received none, unless experience be a jewel. That I have purchased at an infinite rate, and that hath taught me to say this: Love like a shadow flies when substance love pursues, Pursuing that that flies, and flying what pursues.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Have you received no promise of satisfaction at her hands?

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Never.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Have you importuned her to such a purpose?

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Never.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Of what quality was your love, then?

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Like a fair house built on another man's ground, so that I have lost my edifice by mistaking the place where I erected it.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: To what purpose have you unfolded this to me?

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: When I have told you that, I have told you all. Some say that though she appear honest to me, yet in other places she enlargeth her mirth so far that there is shrewd construction made of her. Now, Sir John, here is the heart of my purpose: you are a gentleman of excellent breeding, admirable discourse, of great admittance, authentic in your place and person, generally allowed for your many warlike, courtlike, and learned preparations.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: O, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Believe it, for you know it. There is money. Spend it, spend it; spend more; spend all I have; only give me so much of your time in exchange of it as to lay an amiable siege to the honesty of this Ford's wife. Use your art of wooing, win her to consent to you. If any man may, you may as soon as any.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Would it apply well to the vehemency of your affection that I should win what you would enjoy? Methinks you prescribe to yourself very preposterously.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: O, understand my drift. She dwells so securely on the excellency of her honour that the folly of my soul dares not present itself; she is too bright to be looked against. Now, could I come to her with any detection in my hand, my desires had instance and argument to commend themselves. I could drive her then from the ward of her purity, her reputation, her marriage vow, and a thousand other her defences, which now are too too strongly embattled against me. What say you to't, Sir John?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Master Brook, I will first make bold with your money; next, give me your hand; and last, as I am a gentleman, you shall, if you will, enjoy Ford's wife.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: O good sir!

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: I say you shall.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Want no money, Sir John; you shall want none.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Want no Mistress Ford, Master Brook; you shall want none. I shall be with her, I may tell you, by her own appointment; even as you came in to me, her assistant or go-between parted from me. I say I shall be with her between ten and eleven, for at that time the jealous rascally knave her husband will be forth. Come you to me at night. You shall know how I speed.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: I am blessed in your acquaintance. Do you know Ford, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Hang him, poor cuckoldly knave! I know him not. Yet I wrong him to call him poor. They say the jealous wittolly knave hath masses of money, for the which his wife seems to me well-favoured. I will use her as the key of the cuckoldly rogue's coffer, and there's my harvest-home.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: I would you knew Ford, sir, that you might avoid him if you saw him.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Hang him, mechanical salt-butter rogue! I will stare him out of his wits, I will awe him with my cudgel; it shall hang like a meteor o'er the cuckold's horns. Master Brook, thou shalt know I will predominate over the peasant, and thou shalt lie with his wife. Come to me soon at night. Ford's a knave, and I will aggravate his style. Thou, Master Brook, shalt know him for knave and cuckold. Come to me soon at night.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: What a damned epicurean rascal is this! My heart is ready to crack with impatience. Who says this is improvident jealousy? My wife hath sent to him, the hour is fixed, the match is made. Would any man have thought this? See the hell of having a false woman: my bed shall be abused, my coffers ransacked, my reputation gnawn at; and I shall not only receive this villanous wrong, but stand under the adoption of abominable terms, and by him that does me this wrong. Terms, names! Amaimon sounds well; Lucifer, well; Barbason, well; yet they are devils' additions, the names of fiends. But cuckold? Wittol? Cuckold? The devil himself hath not such a name. Page is an ass, a secure ass; he will trust his wife, he will not be jealous. I will rather trust a Fleming with my butter, Parson Hugh the Welshman with my cheese, an Irishman with my aqua-vitae bottle, or a thief to walk my ambling gelding, than my wife with herself. Then she plots, then she ruminates, then she devises; and what they think in their hearts they may effect, they will break their hearts but they will effect. God be praised for my jealousy! Eleven o'clock the hour. I will prevent this, detect my wife, be revenged on Falstaff, and laugh at Page. I will about it. Better three hours too soon than a minute too late. Fie, fie, fie! Cuckold, cuckold, cuckold!

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Jack Rugby!

dialogues.speaker: Rugby
dialogues.line: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Vat is de clock, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Rugby
dialogues.line: 'Tis past the hour, sir, that Sir Hugh promised to meet.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: By gar, he has save his soul, dat he is no come. He has pray his Pible well dat he is no come. By gar, Jack Rugby, he is dead already, if he be come.

dialogues.speaker: Rugby
dialogues.line: He is wise, sir; he knew your worship would kill him if he came.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: By gar, de herring is no dead so as I vill kill him. Take your rapier, Jack; I vill tell you how I vill kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Rugby
dialogues.line: Alas, sir, I cannot fence.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Villainy, take your rapier.

dialogues.speaker: Rugby
dialogues.line: Forbear; here's company.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: God bless thee, bully doctor!

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: God save you, Master Doctor Caius!

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Now, good Master Doctor!

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Give you good morrow, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Vat be all you, one, two, tree, four, come for?

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: To see thee fight, to see thee foin, to see thee traverse; to see thee here, to see thee there; to see thee pass thy punto, thy stock, thy reverse, thy distance, thy montant. Is he dead, my Ethiopian? Is he dead, my Francisco? Ha, bully? What says my Aesculapius, my Galen, my heart of elder, ha? Is he dead, bully stale? Is he dead?

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: By gar, he is de coward Jack-priest of de vorld. He is not show his face.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Thou art a Castalion King Urinal Hector of Greece, my boy!

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: I pray you, bear witness that me have stay six or seven, two, tree hours for him, and he is no come.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: He is the wiser man, Master doctor. He is a curer of souls, and you a curer of bodies. If you should fight, you go against the hair of your professions. Is it not true, Master Page?

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Master Shallow, you have yourself been a great fighter, though now a man of peace.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Bodykins, Master Page, though I now be old, and of the peace, if I see a sword out, my finger itches to make one. Though we are justices and doctors and churchmen, Master Page, we have some salt of our youth in us. We are the sons of women, Master Page.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: 'Tis true, Master Shallow.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: It will be found so, Master Page.-Master Doctor Caius, I come to fetch you home. I am sworn of the peace. You have showed yourself a wise physician, and Sir Hugh hath shown himself a wise and patient churchman. You must go with me, Master Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Pardon, guest justice.-A word, Monsieur Mockwater.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Mockvater? Vat is dat?

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Mockwater, in our English tongue, is valour, bully.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: By gar, then I have as much mockvater as de Englishman. Scurvy jack-dog priest! By gar, me vill cut his ears.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: He will clapper-claw thee tightly, bully.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Clapper-de-claw? Vat is dat?

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: That is, he will make thee amends.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: By gar, me do look he shall clapper-de-claw me, for, by gar, me vill have it.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: And I will provoke him to't, or let him wag.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Me tank you for dat.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: And, moreover, bully-but first, Master guest, and Master Page, and eke Cavaliero Slender, go you through the town to Frogmore.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Sir Hugh is there, is he?

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: He is there. See what humour he is in; and I will bring the doctor about by the fields. Will it do well?

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: We will do it. PAGE, SHALLOW and SLENDER Adieu, good Master Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: By gar, me vill kill de priest, for he speak for a jackanape to Anne Page.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Let him die. Sheathe thy impatience; throw cold water on thy choler. Go about the fields with me through Frogmore. I will bring thee where Mistress Anne Page is, at a farm-house a-feasting, and thou shalt woo her. Cried game! Said I well?

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: By gar, me tank you for dat. By gar, I love you; and I shall procure-a you de good guest: de earl, de knight, de lords, de gentlemen, my patients.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: For the which I will be thy adversary toward Anne Page. Said I well?

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: By gar, 'tis good; vell said.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Let us wag, then.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Come at my heels, Jack Rugby.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: I pray you now, good Master Slender's servingman, and friend Simple by your name, which way have you looked for Master Caius, that calls himself doctor of physic?

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, the Petty-ward, the Park-ward, every way; old Windsor way, and every way but the town way.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: I most fehemently desire you, you will also look that way.

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: I will, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Pless my soul, how full of cholers I am, and trempling of mind! I shall be glad if he have deceived me. How melancholies I am! I will knog his urinals about his knave's costard when I have good opportunities for the 'ork. Pless my soul! _To shallow rivers, to whose falls Melodious birds sings madrigals. There will we make our peds of roses And a thousand fragrant posies. To shallow_- Mercy on me, I have a great dispositions to cry. _Melodious birds sing madrigals- Whenas I sat in Pabylon- And a thousand vagram posies. To shallow rivers, to whose falls Melodious birds sing madrigals._

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: Yonder he is, coming this way, Sir Hugh.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: He's welcome.  _To shallow rivers, to whose falls-_ Heaven prosper the right! What weapons is he?

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: No weapons, sir. There comes my master, Master Shallow, and another gentleman, from Frogmore, over the stile, this way.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Pray you, give me my gown-or else keep it in your arms.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: How now, Master Parson? Good morrow, good Sir Hugh. Keep a gamester from the dice, and a good student from his book, and it is wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Ah, sweet Anne Page!

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: God save you, good Sir Hugh!

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: God pless you from his mercy sake, all of you!

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: What, the sword and the word? Do you study them both, Master Parson?

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: And youthful still-in your doublet and hose, this raw rheumatic day?

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: There is reasons and causes for it.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: We are come to you to do a good office, Master Parson.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Fery well; what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Yonder is a most reverend gentleman who, belike having received wrong by some person, is at most odds with his own gravity and patience that ever you saw.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: I have lived fourscore years and upward; I never heard a man of his place, gravity, and learning, so wide of his own respect.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: What is he?

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: I think you know him: Master Doctor Caius, the renowned French physician.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Got's will and His passion of my heart! I had as lief you would tell me of a mess of porridge.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: He has no more knowledge in Hibbocrates and Galen, and he is a knave besides, a cowardly knave as you would desires to be acquainted withal.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: I warrant you, he's the man should fight with him.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: O, sweet Anne Page!

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: It appears so by his weapons. Keep them asunder. Here comes Doctor Caius.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Nay, good Master Parson, keep in your weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: So do you, good Master Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Disarm them, and let them question. Let them keep their limbs whole and hack our English.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: I pray you, let-a me speak a word with your ear. Verefore will you not meet-a me?

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Pray you, use your patience. In good time.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: By gar, you are de coward, de Jack dog, John ape.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Pray you, let us not be laughing stocks to other men's humours. I desire you in friendship, and I will one way or other make you amends.  By Jeshu, I will knog your urinal about your knave's cogscomb.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: _Diable!_ Jack Rugby, mine Host de Jarteer, have I not stay for him to kill him? Have I not, at de place I did appoint?

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: As I am a Christians soul, now look you, this is the place appointed. I'll be judgment by mine host of the Garter.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Peace, I say, Gallia and Gaul, French and Welsh, soul-curer and body-curer!

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Ay, dat is very good; excellent.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Peace, I say! Hear mine host of the Garter. Am I politic? Am I subtle? Am I a Machiavel? Shall I lose my doctor? No, he gives me the potions and the motions. Shall I lose my parson, my priest, my Sir Hugh? No, he gives me the proverbs and the no-verbs.  Give me thy hand, terrestrial; so.  Give me thy hand, celestial; so. Boys of art, I have deceived you both. I have directed you to wrong places. Your hearts are mighty, your skins are whole, and let burnt sack be the issue. Come, lay their swords to pawn. Follow me, lads of peace, follow, follow, follow.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Afore God, a mad host! Follow, gentlemen, follow.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: O, sweet Anne Page!

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Ha, do I perceive dat? Have you make-a de sot of us, ha, ha?

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: This is well, he has made us his vlouting-stog. I desire you that we may be friends, and let us knog our prains together to be revenge on this same scall, scurvy, cogging companion, the host of the Garter.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: By gar, with all my heart. He promise to bring me where is Anne Page; by gar, he deceive me too.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Well, I will smite his noddles. Pray you follow.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Nay, keep your way, little gallant. You were wont to be a follower, but now you are a leader. Whether had you rather, lead mine eyes, or eye your master's heels?

dialogues.speaker: Robin
dialogues.line: I had rather, forsooth, go before you like a man than follow him like a dwarf.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: O, you are a flattering boy! Now I see you'll be a courtier.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Well met, Mistress Page. Whither go you?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Truly, sir, to see your wife. Is she at home?

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Ay, and as idle as she may hang together, for want of company. I think if your husbands were dead you two would marry.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Be sure of that-two other husbands.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Where had you this pretty weathercock?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: I cannot tell what the dickens his name is my husband had him of. What do you call your knight's name, sirrah?

dialogues.speaker: Robin
dialogues.line: Sir John Falstaff.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Sir John Falstaff!

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: He, he; I can never hit on's name. There is such a league between my good man and he! Is your wife at home indeed?

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Indeed she is.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: By your leave, sir, I am sick till I see her.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Has Page any brains? Hath he any eyes? Hath he any thinking? Sure, they sleep; he hath no use of them. Why, this boy will carry a letter twenty mile as easy as a cannon will shoot point-blank twelve score. He pieces out his wife's inclination, he gives her folly motion and advantage. And now she's going to my wife, and Falstaff's boy with her. A man may hear this shower sing in the wind. And Falstaff's boy with her! Good plots they are laid, and our revolted wives share damnation together. Well, I will take him, then torture my wife, pluck the borrowed veil of modesty from the so-seeming Mistress Page, divulge Page himself for a secure and wilful Actaeon, and to these violent proceedings all my neighbours shall cry aim.  The clock gives me my cue, and my assurance bids me search. There I shall find Falstaff. I shall be rather praised for this than mocked, for it is as positive as the earth is firm that Falstaff is there. I will go. SHALLOW, PAGE, etc. Well met, Master Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Trust me, a good knot. I have good cheer at home, and I pray you all go with me.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: I must excuse myself, Master Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: And so must I, sir; we have appointed to dine with Mistress Anne, and I would not break with her for more money than I'll speak of.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: We have lingered about a match between Anne Page and my cousin Slender, and this day we shall have our answer.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: I hope I have your good will, father Page.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: You have, Master Slender, I stand wholly for you.-But my wife, Master doctor, is for you altogether.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Ay, be-gar; and de maid is love-a me! My nursh-a Quickly tell me so mush.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: What say you to young Master Fenton? He capers, he dances, he has eyes of youth, he writes verses, he speaks holiday, he smells April and May. He will carry 't, he will carry 't. 'Tis in his buttons he will carry 't.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Not by my consent, I promise you. The gentleman is of no having. He kept company with the wild Prince and Poins. He is of too high a region, he knows too much. No, he shall not knit a knot in his fortunes with the finger of my substance. If he take her, let him take her simply. The wealth I have waits on my consent, and my consent goes not that way.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: I beseech you, heartily, some of you go home with me to dinner. Besides your cheer, you shall have sport: I will show you a monster. Master Doctor, you shall go; so shall you, Master Page, and you, Sir Hugh.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Well, fare you well. We shall have the freer wooing at Master Page's.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Go home, John Rugby; I come anon.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Farewell, my hearts. I will to my honest knight Falstaff, and drink canary with him.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: I think I shall drink in pipe-wine first with him; I'll make him dance.-Will you go, gentles?

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Have with you to see this monster.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: What, John! What, Robert!

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Quickly, quickly! Is the buck-basket-

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: I warrant.-What, Robin, I say! Enter John and Robert with a great buck-basket.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Come, come, come.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Here, set it down.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Give your men the charge; we must be brief.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Marry, as I told you before, John and Robert, be ready here hard by in the brew-house; and when I suddenly call you, come forth, and, without any pause or staggering, take this basket on your shoulders.
