That done, trudge with it in all haste, and carry it among the whitsters in Datchet Mead, and there empty it in the muddy ditch close by the Thames side.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: You will do it?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: I ha' told them over and over, they lack no direction.-Be gone, and come when you are called.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Here comes little Robin.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: How now, my eyas-musket, what news with you?

dialogues.speaker: Robin
dialogues.line: My Master, Sir John, is come in at your back door, Mistress Ford, and requests your company.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: You little Jack-a-Lent, have you been true to us?

dialogues.speaker: Robin
dialogues.line: Ay, I'll be sworn. My master knows not of your being here, and hath threatened to put me into everlasting liberty if I tell you of it; for he swears he'll turn me away.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Thou'rt a good boy, this secrecy of thine shall be a tailor to thee, and shall make thee a new doublet and hose. I'll go hide me.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Do so.-Go tell thy master I am alone. Mistress Page, remember you your cue.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: I warrant thee. If I do not act it, hiss me.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Go to, then. We'll use this unwholesome humidity, this gross watery pumpion; we'll teach him to know turtles from jays.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: "Have I caught thee, my heavenly jewel?" Why, now let me die, for I have lived long enough. This is the period of my ambition. O this blessed hour!

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: O, sweet Sir John!

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Mistress Ford, I cannot cog, I cannot prate, Mistress Ford. Now shall I sin in my wish: I would thy husband were dead. I'll speak it before the best lord: I would make thee my lady.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: I your lady, Sir John? Alas, I should be a pitiful lady.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Let the court of France show me such another. I see how thine eye would emulate the diamond. Thou hast the right arched beauty of the brow that becomes the ship-tire, the tire-valiant, or any tire of Venetian admittance.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: A plain kerchief, Sir John. My brows become nothing else, nor that well neither.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: By the Lord, thou art a traitor to say so. Thou wouldst make an absolute courtier, and the firm fixture of thy foot would give an excellent motion to thy gait in a semi-circled farthingale. I see what thou wert, if Fortune thy foe were not, Nature thy friend. Come, thou canst not hide it.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Believe me, there's no such thing in me.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: What made me love thee? Let that persuade thee there's something extraordinary in thee. Come, I cannot cog and say thou art this and that, like a many of these lisping hawthorn buds that come like women in men's apparel, and smell like Bucklersbury in simple-time. I cannot. But I love thee, none but thee; and thou deservest it.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Do not betray me, sir; I fear you love Mistress Page.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Thou mightst as well say I love to walk by the Counter gate, which is as hateful to me as the reek of a lime-kiln.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Well, heaven knows how I love you, and you shall one day find it.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Keep in that mind, I'll deserve it.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Nay, I must tell you, so you do; or else I could not be in that mind.

dialogues.speaker: Robin
dialogues.line: Mistress Ford, Mistress Ford, here's Mistress Page at the door, sweating and blowing and looking wildly, and would needs speak with you presently.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: She shall not see me; I will ensconce me behind the arras.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Pray you, do so; she's a very tattling woman. What's the matter? How now?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: O Mistress Ford, what have you done? You're shamed, you're overthrown, you're undone for ever!

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: What's the matter, good Mistress Page?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: O well-a-day, Mistress Ford, having an honest man to your husband, to give him such cause of suspicion!

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: What cause of suspicion?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: What cause of suspicion? Out upon you! How am I mistook in you!

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Why, alas, what's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Your husband's coming hither, woman, with all the officers in Windsor, to search for a gentleman that he says is here now in the house, by your consent, to take an ill advantage of his absence. You are undone.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: 'Tis not so, I hope.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Pray heaven it be not so, that you have such a man here! But 'tis most certain your husband's coming, with half Windsor at his heels, to search for such a one. I come before to tell you. If you know yourself clear, why, I am glad of it; but if you have a friend here, convey, convey him out. Be not amazed, call all your senses to you; defend your reputation, or bid farewell to your good life for ever.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: What shall I do? There is a gentleman, my dear friend; and I fear not mine own shame as much as his peril. I had rather than a thousand pound he were out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: For shame! Never stand "you had rather" and "you had rather". Your husband's here at hand. Bethink you of some conveyance. In the house you cannot hide him. O, how have you deceived me! Look, here is a basket. If he be of any reasonable stature, he may creep in here; and throw foul linen upon him, as if it were going to bucking. Or-it is whiting-time-send him by your two men to Datchet Mead.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: He's too big to go in there. What shall I do?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Let me see 't, let me see 't! O, let me see 't! I'll in, I'll in. Follow your friend's counsel. I'll in.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: What, Sir John Falstaff? Are these your letters, knight?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: I love thee, and none but thee. Help me away. Let me creep in here. I'll never-

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Help to cover your master, boy.-Call your men, Mistress Ford.-You dissembling knight!

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: What, John! Robert! John! Go, take up these clothes here, quickly. Where's the cowl-staff? Look how you drumble! Carry them to the laundress in Datchet Mead; quickly, come.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Pray you come near. If I suspect without cause, why then make sport at me, then let me be your jest; I deserve it.-How now? Whither bear you this? JOHN and ROBERT. To the laundress, forsooth.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Why, what have you to do whither they bear it? You were best meddle with buck-washing!

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Buck? I would I could wash myself of the buck! Buck, buck, buck! Ay, buck! I warrant you, buck, and of the season too, it shall appear. Gentlemen, I have dreamed tonight; I'll tell you my dream. Here, here, here be my keys. Ascend my chambers, search, seek, find out. I'll warrant we'll unkennel the fox. Let me stop this way first.  So, now uncape.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Good Master Ford, be contented: you wrong yourself too much.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: True, Master Page.-Up, gentlemen, you shall see sport anon. Follow me, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: This is fery fantastical humours and jealousies.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: By gar, 'tis no the fashion of France; it is not jealous in France.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Nay, follow him, gentlemen; see the issue of his search.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Is there not a double excellency in this?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: I know not which pleases me better, that my husband is deceived, or Sir John.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: What a taking was he in when your husband asked who was in the basket!

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: I am half afraid he will have need of washing, so throwing him into the water will do him a benefit.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Hang him, dishonest rascal! I would all of the same strain were in the same distress.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: I think my husband hath some special suspicion of Falstaff's being here, for I never saw him so gross in his jealousy till now.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: I will lay a plot to try that, and we will yet have more tricks with Falstaff. His dissolute disease will scarce obey this medicine.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Shall we send that foolish carrion Mistress Quickly to him, and excuse his throwing into the water, and give him another hope, to betray him to another punishment?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: We will do it. Let him be sent for tomorrow eight o'clock to have amends.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: I cannot find him. Maybe the knave bragged of that he could not compass.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Heard you that?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: You use me well, Master Ford, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Ay, I do so.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Heaven make you better than your thoughts!

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Amen!

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: You do yourself mighty wrong, Master Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Ay, ay; I must bear it.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: If there be anypody in the house, and in the chambers, and in the coffers, and in the presses, heaven forgive my sins at the day of judgment!

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Be gar, nor I too; there is nobodies.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Fie, fie, Master Ford, are you not ashamed? What spirit, what devil suggests this imagination? I would not ha' your distemper in this kind for the wealth of Windsor Castle.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: 'Tis my fault, Master Page. I suffer for it.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: You suffer for a pad conscience. Your wife is as honest a 'omans as I will desires among five thousand, and five hundred too.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: By gar, I see 'tis an honest woman.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Well, I promised you a dinner. Come, come, walk in the park. I pray you pardon me; I will hereafter make known to you why I have done this. Come, wife, come, Mistress Page, I pray you pardon me. Pray heartily, pardon me.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Let's go in, gentlemen; but, trust me, we'll mock him. I do invite you tomorrow morning to my house to breakfast; after, we'll a-birding together; I have a fine hawk for the bush. Shall it be so?

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Anything.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: If there is one, I shall make two in the company.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: If there be one or two, I shall make-a the turd.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Pray you go, Master Page.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: I pray you now, remembrance tomorrow on the lousy knave, mine host.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Dat is good, by gar, with all my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: A lousy knave, to have his gibes and his mockeries!

dialogues.speaker: Fenton
dialogues.line: I see I cannot get thy father's love; Therefore no more turn me to him, sweet Nan.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Alas, how then?

dialogues.speaker: Fenton
dialogues.line: Why, thou must be thyself. He doth object I am too great of birth, And that my state being galled with my expense, I seek to heal it only by his wealth. Besides these, other bars he lays before me: My riots past, my wild societies- And tells me 'tis a thing impossible I should love thee but as a property.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Maybe he tells you true.

dialogues.speaker: Fenton
dialogues.line: No, heaven so speed me in my time to come! Albeit I will confess thy father's wealth Was the first motive that I wooed thee, Anne, Yet, wooing thee, I found thee of more value Than stamps in gold or sums in sealed bags. And 'tis the very riches of thyself That now I aim at.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Gentle Master Fenton, Yet seek my father's love, still seek it, sir. If opportunity and humblest suit Cannot attain it, why then-hark you hither.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Break their talk, Mistress Quickly. My kinsman shall speak for himself.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: I'll make a shaft or a bolt on 't. 'Slid, 'tis but venturing.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Be not dismayed.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: No, she shall not dismay me. I care not for that, but that I am afeard.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Hark ye, Master Slender would speak a word with you.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: I come to him.  This is my father's choice. O, what a world of vile ill-favoured faults Looks handsome in three hundred pounds a year!

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: And how does good Master Fenton? Pray you, a word with you.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: She's coming; to her, coz. O boy, thou hadst a father!

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: I had a father, Mistress Anne; my uncle can tell you good jests of him.-Pray you, uncle, tell Mistress Anne the jest how my father stole two geese out of a pen, good uncle.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Mistress Anne, my cousin loves you.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Ay, that I do, as well as I love any woman in Gloucestershire.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: He will maintain you like a gentlewoman.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Ay, that I will, come cut and long-tail, under the degree of a squire.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: He will make you a hundred and fifty pounds jointure.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Good Master Shallow, let him woo for himself.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Marry, I thank you for it, I thank you for that good comfort.-She calls you, coz; I'll leave you.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Now, Master Slender.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Now, good Mistress Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: What is your will?

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: My will? 'Od's heartlings, that's a pretty jest indeed! I ne'er made my will yet, I thank heaven. I am not such a sickly creature, I give heaven praise.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: I mean, Master Slender, what would you with me?

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Truly, for mine own part I would little or nothing with you. Your father and my uncle hath made motions. If it be my luck, so; if not, happy man be his dole. They can tell you how things go better than I can. You may ask your father. Here he comes.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Now, Master Slender.-Love him, daughter Anne.- Why, how now? What does Master Fenton here? You wrong me, sir, thus still to haunt my house. I told you, sir, my daughter is disposed of.

dialogues.speaker: Fenton
dialogues.line: Nay, Master Page, be not impatient.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Good Master Fenton, come not to my child.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: She is no match for you.

dialogues.speaker: Fenton
dialogues.line: Sir, will you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: No, good Master Fenton.- Come, Master Shallow; come, son Slender, in.- Knowing my mind, you wrong me, Master Fenton.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Speak to Mistress Page.

dialogues.speaker: Fenton
dialogues.line: Good Mistress Page, for that I love your daughter In such a righteous fashion as I do, Perforce, against all checks, rebukes, and manners, I must advance the colours of my love And not retire. Let me have your good will.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Good mother, do not marry me to yond fool.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: I mean it not; I seek you a better husband.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: That's my master, Master Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Alas, I had rather be set quick i' th' earth, And bowled to death with turnips.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Come, trouble not yourself, good Master Fenton, I will not be your friend, nor enemy. My daughter will I question how she loves you, And as I find her, so am I affected. Till then, farewell, sir. She must needs go in; Her father will be angry.

dialogues.speaker: Fenton
dialogues.line: Farewell, gentle mistress. Farewell, Nan.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: This is my doing now. "Nay," said I, "will you cast away your child on a fool, and a physician? Look on Master Fenton." This is my doing.

dialogues.speaker: Fenton
dialogues.line: I thank thee; and I pray thee, once tonight Give my sweet Nan this ring. There's for thy pains.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Now Heaven send thee good fortune! A kind heart he hath. A woman would run through fire and water for such a kind heart. But yet I would my master had Mistress Anne, or I would Master Slender had her; or, in sooth, I would Master Fenton had her. I will do what I can for them all three, for so I have promised and I'll be as good as my word-but speciously for Master Fenton. Well, I must of another errand to Sir John Falstaff from my two mistresses. What a beast am I to slack it!

scenes.location: A room in the Garter Inn

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Bardolph, I say!

dialogues.speaker: Bardolph
dialogues.line: Here, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Go fetch me a quart of sack; put a toast in 't. Have I lived to be carried in a basket like a barrow of butcher's offal, and to be thrown in the Thames? Well, if I be served such another trick, I'll have my brains ta'en out and buttered, and give them to a dog for a New Year's gift. 'Sblood, the rogues slighted me into the river with as little remorse as they would have drowned a blind bitch's puppies, fifteen i' the litter; and you may know by my size that I have a kind of alacrity in sinking; if the bottom were as deep as hell, I should down. I had been drowned, but that the shore was shelvy and shallow-a death that I abhor, for the water swells a man, and what a thing should I have been when I had been swelled! I should have been a mountain of mummy.

dialogues.speaker: Bardolph
dialogues.line: Here's Mistress Quickly, sir, to speak with you.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Come, let me pour in some sack to the Thames water, for my belly's as cold as if I had swallowed snowballs for pills to cool the reins. Call her in.

dialogues.speaker: Bardolph
dialogues.line: Come in, woman.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: By your leave, I cry you mercy. Give your worship good morrow.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Take away these chalices. Go, brew me a pottle of sack finely.

dialogues.speaker: Bardolph
dialogues.line: With eggs, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Simple of itself. I'll no pullet sperm in my brewage. How now?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, I come to your worship from Mistress Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Mistress Ford? I have had ford enough. I was thrown into the ford, I have my belly full of ford.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Alas the day, good heart, that was not her fault. She does so take on with her men; they mistook their erection.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: So did I mine, to build upon a foolish woman's promise.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Well, she laments, sir, for it, that it would yearn your heart to see it. Her husband goes this morning a-birding; she desires you once more to come to her, between eight and nine. I must carry her word quickly. She'll make you amends, I warrant you.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Well, I will visit her. Tell her so, and bid her think what a man is. Let her consider his frailty, and then judge of my merit.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: I will tell her.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Do so. Between nine and ten, sayst thou?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Eight and nine, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Well, be gone. I will not miss her.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Peace be with you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: I marvel I hear not of Master Brook; he sent me word to stay within. I like his money well. O, here he comes.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: God bless you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Now, Master Brook, you come to know what hath passed between me and Ford's wife?

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: That indeed, Sir John, is my business.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Master Brook, I will not lie to you. I was at her house the hour she appointed me.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: And how sped you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Very ill-favouredly, Master Brook.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: How so, sir? Did she change her determination?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: No. Master Brook, but the peaking cornuto her husband, Master Brook, dwelling in a continual 'larum of jealousy, comes me in the instant of our encounter, after we had embraced, kissed, protested, and, as it were, spoke the prologue of our comedy; and at his heels a rabble of his companions, thither provoked and instigated by his distemper, and, forsooth, to search his house for his wife's love.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: What, while you were there?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: While I was there.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: And did he search for you, and could not find you?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: You shall hear. As good luck would have it, comes in one Mistress Page, gives intelligence of Ford's approach; and, in her invention and Ford's wife's distraction, they conveyed me into a buck-basket.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: A buck-basket!

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: By the Lord, a buck-basket! Rammed me in with foul shirts and smocks, socks, foul stockings, greasy napkins, that, Master Brook, there was the rankest compound of villainous smell that ever offended nostril.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: And how long lay you there?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Nay, you shall hear, Master Brook, what I have suffered to bring this woman to evil for your good. Being thus crammed in the basket, a couple of Ford's knaves, his hinds, were called forth by their mistress to carry me in the name of foul clothes to Datchet Lane. They took me on their shoulders, met the jealous knave their master in the door, who asked them once or twice what they had in their basket. I quaked for fear lest the lunatic knave would have searched it; but Fate, ordaining he should be a cuckold, held his hand. Well, on went he for a search, and away went I for foul clothes. But mark the sequel, Master Brook. I suffered the pangs of three several deaths: first, an intolerable fright to be detected with a jealous rotten bell-wether; next, to be compassed like a good bilbo in the circumference of a peck, hilt to point, heel to head; and then, to be stopped in, like a strong distillation, with stinking clothes that fretted in their own grease. Think of that, a man of my kidney, think of that-that am as subject to heat as butter; a man of continual dissolution and thaw. It was a miracle to 'scape suffocation. And in the height of this bath, when I was more than half stewed in grease, like a Dutch dish, to be thrown into the Thames and cooled, glowing hot, in that surge, like a horseshoe! Think of that-hissing hot-think of that, Master Brook.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: In good sadness, sir, I am sorry that for my sake you have suffered all this. My suit, then, is desperate. You'll undertake her no more?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Master Brook, I will be thrown into Etna, as I have been into Thames, ere I will leave her thus. Her husband is this morning gone a-birding; I have received from her another embassy of meeting. 'Twixt eight and nine is the hour, Master Brook.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: 'Tis past eight already, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Is it? I will then address me to my appointment. Come to me at your convenient leisure, and you shall know how I speed; and the conclusion shall be crowned with your enjoying her. Adieu. You shall have her, Master Brook. Master Brook, you shall cuckold Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Hum! Ha! Is this a vision? Is this a dream? Do I sleep? Master Ford, awake; awake, Master Ford! There's a hole made in your best coat, Master Ford. This 'tis to be married; this 'tis to have linen and buck-baskets! Well, I will proclaim myself what I am. I will now take the lecher. He is at my house. He cannot scape me. 'Tis impossible he should. He cannot creep into a half-penny purse, nor into a pepperbox. But, lest the devil that guides him should aid him, I will search impossible places. Though what I am I cannot avoid, yet to be what I would not shall not make me tame. If I have horns to make one mad, let the proverb go with me: I'll be horn-mad.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Is he at Master Ford's already, think'st thou?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Sure he is by this; or will be presently. But truly he is very courageous mad about his throwing into the water. Mistress Ford desires you to come suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: I'll be with her by and by. I'll but bring my young man here to school. Look where his master comes; 'tis a playing day, I see. How now, Sir Hugh, no school today?

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: No, Master Slender is let the boys leave to play.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Blessing of his heart!

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Sir Hugh, my husband says my son profits nothing in the world at his book. I pray you ask him some questions in his accidence.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Come hither, William. Hold up your head, come.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Come on, sirrah. Hold up your head. Answer your master, be not afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: William, how many numbers is in nouns?

dialogues.speaker: William
dialogues.line: Two.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Truly, I thought there had been one number more, because they say "'Od's nouns."

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Peace your tattlings! What is "fair," William?

dialogues.speaker: William
dialogues.line: _Pulcher_.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Polecats? There are fairer things than polecats, sure.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: You are a very simplicity 'oman; I pray you, peace.-What is _lapis_, William?

dialogues.speaker: William
dialogues.line: A stone.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: And what is "a stone," William?

dialogues.speaker: William
dialogues.line: A pebble.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: No, it is _lapis_. I pray you remember in your prain.

dialogues.speaker: William
dialogues.line: _Lapis_.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: That is a good William. What is he, William, that does lend articles?

dialogues.speaker: William
dialogues.line: Articles are borrowed of the pronoun, and be thus declined: _singulariter, nominativo, hic, haec, hoc_.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: _Nominativo, hig, haeg, hog_, pray you, mark: _genitivo, huius_. Well, what is your accusative case?

dialogues.speaker: William
dialogues.line: _Accusativo, hinc_.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: I pray you, have your remembrance, child. _Accusativo, hung, hang, hog_.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: "Hang-hog" is Latin for bacon, I warrant you.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Leave your prabbles, 'oman.-What is the focative case, William?

dialogues.speaker: William
dialogues.line: O-_vocativo_-O-

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Remember, William; focative is _caret_.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: And that's a good root.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: 'Oman, forbear.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Peace.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: What is your genitive case plural, William?

dialogues.speaker: William
dialogues.line: Genitive case?

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Ay.

dialogues.speaker: William
dialogues.line: Genitive: _horum, harum, horum_.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Vengeance of Jenny's case, fie on her! Never name her, child, if she be a whore.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: For shame, 'oman.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: You do ill to teach the child such words.-He teaches him to hick and to hack, which they'll do fast enough of themselves; and to call "whore 'm"!-Fie upon you!

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: 'Oman, art thou lunatics? Hast thou no understandings for thy cases, and the numbers of the genders? Thou art as foolish Christian creatures as I would desires.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Prithee, hold thy peace.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Show me now, William, some declensions of your pronouns.

dialogues.speaker: William
dialogues.line: Forsooth, I have forgot.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: It is _qui, quae, quod_. If you forget your _quis_, your _quaes_, and your _quods_, you must be preeches. Go your ways and play, go.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: He is a better scholar than I thought he was.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: He is a good sprag memory. Farewell, Mistress Page.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Adieu, good Sir Hugh. Get you home, boy. Come, we stay too long.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Mistress Ford, your sorrow hath eaten up my sufferance. I see you are obsequious in your love, and I profess requital to a hair's breadth, not only, Mistress Ford, in the simple office of love, but in all the accoutrement, compliment, and ceremony of it. But are you sure of your husband now?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: He's a-birding, sweet Sir John.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: What ho, gossip Ford, what ho!

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Step into the chamber, Sir John.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: How now, sweetheart, who's at home besides yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Why, none but mine own people.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Indeed?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: No, certainly.  Speak louder.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Truly, I am so glad you have nobody here.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Why, woman, your husband is in his old lunes again. He so takes on yonder with my husband, so rails against all married mankind, so curses all Eve's daughters, of what complexion soever, and so buffets himself on the forehead, crying "Peer out, peer out!" that any madness I ever yet beheld seemed but tameness, civility, and patience, to this his distemper he is in now. I am glad the fat knight is not here.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Why, does he talk of him?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Of none but him, and swears he was carried out, the last time he searched for him, in a basket; protests to my husband he is now here; and hath drawn him and the rest of their company from their sport, to make another experiment of his suspicion. But I am glad the knight is not here. Now he shall see his own foolery.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: How near is he, Mistress Page?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Hard by, at street end. He will be here anon.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: I am undone! The knight is here.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Why, then, you are utterly shamed, and he's but a dead man. What a woman are you! Away with him, away with him! Better shame than murder.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Which way should he go? How should I bestow him? Shall I put him into the basket again?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: No, I'll come no more i' the basket. May I not go out ere he come?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Alas, three of Master Ford's brothers watch the door with pistols, that none shall issue out, otherwise you might slip away ere he came. But what make you here?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: What shall I do? I'll creep up into the chimney.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: There they always use to discharge their birding-pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Creep into the kiln-hole.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: He will seek there, on my word. Neither press, coffer, chest, trunk, well, vault, but he hath an abstract for the remembrance of such places, and goes to them by his note. There is no hiding you in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: I'll go out then.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: If you go out in your own semblance, you die, Sir John-unless you go out disguised.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: How might we disguise him?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Alas the day, I know not. There is no woman's gown big enough for him; otherwise he might put on a hat, a muffler, and a kerchief, and so escape.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Good hearts, devise something. Any extremity rather than a mischief.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: My maid's aunt, the fat woman of Brentford, has a gown above.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: On my word, it will serve him. She's as big as he is. And there's her thrummed hat, and her muffler too.-Run up, Sir John.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Go, go, sweet Sir John. Mistress Page and I will look some linen for your head.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Quick, quick! We'll come dress you straight; put on the gown the while.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: I would my husband would meet him in this shape. He cannot abide the old woman of Brentford; he swears she's a witch, forbade her my house, and hath threatened to beat her.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Heaven guide him to thy husband's cudgel and the devil guide his cudgel afterwards!

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: But is my husband coming?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Ay, in good sadness is he, and talks of the basket too, howsoever he hath had intelligence.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: We'll try that; for I'll appoint my men to carry the basket again, to meet him at the door with it as they did last time.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Nay, but he'll be here presently. Let's go dress him like the witch of Brentford.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: I'll first direct my men what they shall do with the basket. Go up, I'll bring linen for him straight.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Hang him, dishonest varlet! We cannot misuse him enough. We'll leave a proof, by that which we will do, Wives may be merry and yet honest too. We do not act that often jest and laugh; 'Tis old but true: "Still swine eats all the draff."

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Go, sirs, take the basket again on your shoulders. Your master is hard at door; if he bid you set it down, obey him. Quickly, dispatch.

dialogues.speaker: John
dialogues.line: Come, come, take it up.

dialogues.speaker: Robert
dialogues.line: Pray heaven it be not full of knight again.

dialogues.speaker: John
dialogues.line: I hope not, I had lief as bear so much lead.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Ay, but if it prove true, Master Page, have you any way then to unfool me again?-Set down the basket, villain! Somebody call my wife. Youth in a basket! O you panderly rascals! There's a knot, a gin, a pack, a conspiracy against me. Now shall the devil be shamed.-What, wife, I say! Come, come forth! Behold what honest clothes you send forth to bleaching!

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Why, this passes, Master Ford! You are not to go loose any longer; you must be pinioned.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Why, this is lunatics, this is mad as a mad dog.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: Indeed, Master Ford, this is not well, indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: So say I too, sir. Come hither, Mistress Ford-Mistress Ford, the honest woman, the modest wife, the virtuous creature, that hath the jealous fool to her husband! I suspect without cause, mistress, do I?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Heaven be my witness you do, if you suspect me in any dishonesty.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Well said, brazen-face, hold it out.-Come forth, sirrah.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: This passes.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Are you not ashamed? Let the clothes alone.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: I shall find you anon.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: 'Tis unreasonable. Will you take up your wife's clothes? Come, away.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Empty the basket, I say.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Why, man, why?

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Master Page, as I am a man, there was one conveyed out of my house yesterday in this basket. Why may not he be there again? In my house I am sure he is. My intelligence is true, my jealousy is reasonable.-Pluck me out all the linen.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: If you find a man there, he shall die a flea's death.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Here's no man.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: By my fidelity, this is not well, Master Ford, this wrongs you.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Master Ford, you must pray, and not follow the imaginations of your own heart. This is jealousies.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Well, he's not here I seek for.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: No, nor nowhere else but in your brain.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Help to search my house this one time. If I find not what I seek, show no colour for my extremity, let me for ever be your table-sport. Let them say of me "As jealous as Ford, that searched a hollow walnut for his wife's leman." Satisfy me once more, once more search with me.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: What, ho, Mistress Page! Come you and the old woman down; my husband will come into the chamber.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Old woman? What old woman's that?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Why, it is my maid's aunt of Brentford.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: A witch, a quean, an old cozening quean! Have I not forbid her my house? She comes of errands, does she? We are simple men; we do not know what's brought to pass under the profession of fortune-telling. She works by charms, by spells, by the figure, and such daubery as this is, beyond our element. We know nothing.-Come down, you witch, you hag, you! Come down, I say!

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Nay, good sweet husband!-Good gentlemen, let him not strike the old woman.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Come, Mother Prat; come, give me your hand.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: I'll prat her.  Out of my door, you witch, you rag, you baggage, you polecat, you runnion! Out, out! I'll conjure you, I'll fortune-tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Are you not ashamed? I think you have killed the poor woman.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Nay, he will do it. 'Tis a goodly credit for you.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Hang her, witch!

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: By yea and no, I think the 'oman is a witch indeed. I like not when a 'oman has a great peard. I spy a great peard under her muffler.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Will you follow, gentlemen? I beseech you follow, see but the issue of my jealousy. If I cry out thus upon no trail, never trust me when I open again.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Let's obey his humour a little further. Come, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Trust me, he beat him most pitifully.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Nay, by th' mass, that he did not; he beat him most unpitifully, methought.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: I'll have the cudgel hallowed and hung o'er the altar. It hath done meritorious service.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: What think you? May we, with the warrant of womanhood and the witness of a good conscience, pursue him with any further revenge?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: The spirit of wantonness is sure scared out of him. If the devil have him not in fee-simple, with fine and recovery, he will never, I think, in the way of waste, attempt us again.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Shall we tell our husbands how we have served him?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Yes, by all means, if it be but to scrape the figures out of your husband's brains. If they can find in their hearts the poor unvirtuous fat knight shall be any further afflicted, we two will still be the ministers.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: I'll warrant they'll have him publicly shamed, and methinks there would be no period to the jest should he not be publicly shamed.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Come, to the forge with it, then shape it. I would not have things cool.

scenes.location: A room in the Garter Inn

dialogues.speaker: Bardolph
dialogues.line: Sir, the Germans desire to have three of your horses. The Duke himself will be tomorrow at court, and they are going to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: What duke should that be comes so secretly? I hear not of him in the court. Let me speak with the gentlemen. They speak English?

dialogues.speaker: Bardolph
dialogues.line: Ay, sir. I'll call them to you.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: They shall have my horses, but I'll make them pay, I'll sauce them. They have had my house a week at command; I have turned away my other guests. They must come off, I'll sauce them. Come.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: 'Tis one of the best discretions of a 'oman as ever I did look upon.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: And did he send you both these letters at an instant?

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Pardon me, wife. Henceforth, do what thou wilt. I rather will suspect the sun with cold Than thee with wantonness. Now doth thy honour stand, In him that was of late an heretic, As firm as faith.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: 'Tis well, 'tis well, no more. Be not as extreme in submission as in offence. But let our plot go forward. Let our wives Yet once again, to make us public sport, Appoint a meeting with this old fat fellow, Where we may take him and disgrace him for it.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: There is no better way than that they spoke of.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: How? To send him word they'll meet him in the park at midnight? Fie, fie, he'll never come.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: You say he has been thrown in the rivers, and has been grievously peaten as an old 'oman. Methinks there should be terrors in him, that he should not come. Methinks his flesh is punished; he shall have no desires.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: So think I too.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Devise but how you'll use him when he comes, And let us two devise to bring him thither.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: There is an old tale goes that Herne the hunter, Sometime a keeper here in Windsor Forest, Doth all the winter time, at still midnight, Walk round about an oak, with great ragged horns, And there he blasts the tree, and takes the cattle, And makes milch-kine yield blood, and shakes a chain In a most hideous and dreadful manner. You have heard of such a spirit, and well you know The superstitious idle-headed eld Received and did deliver to our age, This tale of Herne the hunter for a truth.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Why, yet there want not many that do fear In deep of night to walk by this Herne's oak. But what of this?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Marry, this is our device, That Falstaff at that oak shall meet with us, Disguised like Herne, with huge horns on his head.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Well, let it not be doubted but he'll come, And in this shape; when you have brought him thither, What shall be done with him? What is your plot?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: That likewise have we thought upon, and thus: Nan Page my daughter, and my little son, And three or four more of their growth, we'll dress Like urchins, oafs and fairies, green and white, With rounds of waxen tapers on their heads And rattles in their hands. Upon a sudden, As Falstaff, she, and I are newly met, Let them from forth a sawpit rush at once With some diffused song; upon their sight We two in great amazedness will fly. Then let them all encircle him about, And fairy-like, to pinch the unclean knight, And ask him why, that hour of fairy revel, In their so sacred paths he dares to tread In shape profane.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: And till he tell the truth, Let the supposed fairies pinch him sound And burn him with their tapers.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: The truth being known, We'll all present ourselves, dis-horn the spirit, And mock him home to Windsor.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: The children must Be practised well to this, or they'll ne'er do 't.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: I will teach the children their behaviours, and I will be like a jackanapes also, to burn the knight with my taber.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: That will be excellent. I'll go buy them vizards.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: My Nan shall be the queen of all the fairies, Finely attired in a robe of white.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: That silk will I go buy.  And in that time Shall Master Slender steal my Nan away, And marry her at Eton.-Go, send to Falstaff straight.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Nay, I'll to him again in name of Brook. He'll tell me all his purpose. Sure, he'll come.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Fear not you that. Go, get us properties And tricking for our fairies.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Let us about it. It is admirable pleasures and fery honest knaveries.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Go, Mistress Ford. Send quickly to Sir John to know his mind. I'll to the Doctor. He hath my good will, And none but he, to marry with Nan Page. That Slender, though well landed, is an idiot, And he my husband best of all affects. The Doctor is well moneyed, and his friends Potent at court. He, none but he, shall have her, Though twenty thousand worthier come to crave her.

scenes.location: A room in the Garter Inn

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: What wouldst thou have, boor? What, thick-skin? Speak, breathe, discuss; brief, short, quick, snap.

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, I come to speak with Sir John Falstaff from Master Slender.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: There's his chamber, his house, his castle, his standing-bed and truckle-bed. 'Tis painted about with the story of the Prodigal, fresh and new. Go, knock and call. He'll speak like an Anthropophaginian unto thee. Knock, I say.

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: There's an old woman, a fat woman, gone up into his chamber. I'll be so bold as stay, sir, till she come down. I come to speak with her, indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Ha? A fat woman? The knight may be robbed. I'll call.-Bully knight! Bully Sir John! Speak from thy lungs military. Art thou there? It is thine host, thine Ephesian, calls.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: How now, mine host?

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Here's a Bohemian-Tartar tarries the coming down of thy fat woman. Let her descend, bully, let her descend. My chambers are honourable. Fie! Privacy? Fie!

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: There was, mine host, an old fat woman even now with me, but she's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: Pray you, sir, was't not the wise woman of Brentford?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Ay, marry was it, mussel-shell. What would you with her?

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: My master, sir, my Master Slender, sent to her, seeing her go through the streets, to know, sir, whether one Nym, sir, that beguiled him of a chain, had the chain or no.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: I spake with the old woman about it.

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: And what says she, I pray, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Marry, she says that the very same man that beguiled Master Slender of his chain cozened him of it.

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: I would I could have spoken with the woman herself. I had other things to have spoken with her too, from him.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: What are they? Let us know.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Ay, come. Quick.

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: I may not conceal them, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Conceal them, or thou diest.

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: Why, sir, they were nothing but about Mistress Anne Page, to know if it were my master's fortune to have her or no.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: 'Tis, 'tis his fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: What sir?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: To have her, or no. Go, say the woman told me so.

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: May I be bold to say so, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Ay, sir; like who more bold?

dialogues.speaker: Simple
dialogues.line: I thank your worship; I shall make my master glad with these tidings.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Thou art clerkly, thou art clerkly, Sir John. Was there a wise woman with thee?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Ay, that there was, mine host; one that hath taught me more wit than ever I learned before in my life; and I paid nothing for it neither, but was paid for my learning.

dialogues.speaker: Bardolph
dialogues.line: Out, alas, sir, cozenage, mere cozenage!

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Where be my horses? Speak well of them, varletto.

dialogues.speaker: Bardolph
dialogues.line: Run away, with the cozeners. For so soon as I came beyond Eton, they threw me off from behind one of them, in a slough of mire, and set spurs and away, like three German devils, three Doctor Faustuses.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: They are gone but to meet the Duke, villain, do not say they be fled. Germans are honest men.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Where is mine host?

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: What is the matter, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Have a care of your entertainments. There is a friend of mine come to town tells me there is three cozen-Germans that has cozened all the hosts of Readings, of Maidenhead, of Colebrook, of horses and money. I tell you for good will, look you. You are wise, and full of gibes and vlouting-stocks, and 'tis not convenient you should be cozened. Fare you well.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Vere is mine host de Jarteer?

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Here, Master Doctor, in perplexity and doubtful dilemma.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: I cannot tell vat is dat, but it is tell-a me dat you make grand preparation for a Duke de Jamany. By my trot, dere is no duke that the court is know to come. I tell you for good will. Adieu.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Hue and cry, villain, go!-Assist me, knight, I am undone.-Fly, run, hue and cry, villain, I am undone!

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: I would all the world might be cozened, for I have been cozened and beaten too. If it should come to the ear of the court how I have been transformed, and how my transformation hath been washed and cudgelled, they would melt me out of my fat drop by drop, and liquor fishermen's boots with me. I warrant they would whip me with their fine wits till I were as crestfallen as a dried pear. I never prospered since I forswore myself at primero. Well, if my wind were but long enough, I would repent. Now, whence come you?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: From the two parties, forsooth.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: The devil take one party and his dam the other, and so they shall be both bestowed. I have suffered more for their sakes, more than the villainous inconstancy of man's disposition is able to bear.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: And have not they suffered? Yes, I warrant, speciously one of them. Mistress Ford, good heart, is beaten black and blue, that you cannot see a white spot about her.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: What tellst thou me of black and blue? I was beaten myself into all the colours of the rainbow, and was like to be apprehended for the witch of Brentford. But that my admirable dexterity of wit, my counterfeiting the action of an old woman, delivered me, the knave constable had set me i' the stocks, i' the common stocks, for a witch.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Sir, let me speak with you in your chamber, you shall hear how things go, and, I warrant, to your content. Here is a letter will say somewhat. Good hearts, what ado here is to bring you together! Sure, one of you does not serve heaven well, that you are so crossed.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Come up into my chamber.

scenes.location: Another room in the Garter Inn

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Master Fenton, talk not to me. My mind is heavy. I will give over all.

dialogues.speaker: Fenton
dialogues.line: Yet hear me speak. Assist me in my purpose, And, as I am a gentleman, I'll give thee A hundred pound in gold more than your loss.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: I will hear you, Master Fenton, and I will, at the least, keep your counsel.

dialogues.speaker: Fenton
dialogues.line: From time to time I have acquainted you With the dear love I bear to fair Anne Page, Who mutually hath answered my affection, So far forth as herself might be her chooser, Even to my wish. I have a letter from her Of such contents as you will wonder at, The mirth whereof so larded with my matter That neither singly can be manifested Without the show of both, wherein fat Falstaff Hath a great scene; the image of the jest I'll show you here at large. Hark, good mine host: Tonight at Herne's oak, just 'twixt twelve and one, Must my sweet Nan present the Fairy Queen- The purpose why is here-in which disguise, While other jests are something rank on foot, Her father hath commanded her to slip Away with Slender, and with him at Eton Immediately to marry. She hath consented. Now, sir, Her mother, even strong against that match And firm for Doctor Caius, hath appointed That he shall likewise shuffle her away, While other sports are tasking of their minds, And at the dean'ry, where a priest attends, Straight marry her. To this her mother's plot She, seemingly obedient, likewise hath Made promise to the doctor. Now thus it rests: Her father means she shall be all in white And in that habit, when Slender sees his time To take her by the hand and bid her go, She shall go with him. Her mother hath intended The better to denote her to the doctor, For they must all be masked and vizarded- That quaint in green she shall be loose enrobed, With ribbons pendant flaring 'bout her head; And when the doctor spies his vantage ripe, To pinch her by the hand, and on that token The maid hath given consent to go with him.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Which means she to deceive, father or mother?

dialogues.speaker: Fenton
dialogues.line: Both, my good host, to go along with me. And here it rests, that you'll procure the vicar To stay for me at church, 'twixt twelve and one, And, in the lawful name of marrying, To give our hearts united ceremony.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Well, husband your device; I'll to the vicar. Bring you the maid, you shall not lack a priest.

dialogues.speaker: Fenton
dialogues.line: So shall I evermore be bound to thee; Besides, I'll make a present recompense.

scenes.location: A room in the Garter Inn

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Prithee, no more prattling. Go. I'll hold. This is the third time; I hope good luck lies in odd numbers. Away, go! They say there is divinity in odd numbers, either in nativity, chance, or death. Away!

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: I'll provide you a chain, and I'll do what I can to get you a pair of horns.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Away, I say; time wears. Hold up your head, and mince. How now, Master Brook! Master Brook, the matter will be known tonight or never. Be you in the park about midnight, at Herne's oak, and you shall see wonders.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Went you not to her yesterday, sir, as you told me you had appointed?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: I went to her, Master Brook, as you see, like a poor old man, but I came from her, Master Brook, like a poor old woman. That same knave Ford, her husband, hath the finest mad devil of jealousy in him, Master Brook, that ever governed frenzy. I will tell you he beat me grievously, in the shape of a woman; for in the shape of man, Master Brook, I fear not Goliath with a weaver's beam, because I know also life is a shuttle. I am in haste. Go along with me; I'll tell you all, Master Brook. Since I plucked geese, played truant, and whipped top, I knew not what 'twas to be beaten till lately. Follow me, I'll tell you strange things of this knave Ford, on whom tonight I will be revenged, and I will deliver his wife into your hand. Follow. Strange things in hand, Master Brook! Follow.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Come, come. We'll couch i' the castle ditch till we see the light of our fairies. Remember, son Slender, my daughter-

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Ay, forsooth. I have spoke with her, and we have a nay-word how to know one another. I come to her in white and cry "mum"; she cries "budget"; and by that we know one another.

dialogues.speaker: Shallow
dialogues.line: That's good too. But what needs either your "mum" or her "budget"? The white will decipher her well enough. It hath struck ten o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: The night is dark. Light and spirits will become it well. Heaven prosper our sport! No man means evil but the devil, and we shall know him by his horns. Let's away; follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Master Doctor, my daughter is in green. When you see your time, take her by the hand, away with her to the deanery, and dispatch it quickly. Go before into the park. We two must go together.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: I know vat I have to do. Adieu.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Fare you well, sir. My husband will not rejoice so much at the abuse of Falstaff as he will chafe at the doctor's marrying my daughter. But 'tis no matter. Better a little chiding than a great deal of heartbreak.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Where is Nan now, and her troop of fairies, and the Welsh devil Hugh?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: They are all couched in a pit hard by Herne's oak, with obscured lights, which, at the very instant of Falstaff's and our meeting, they will at once display to the night.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: That cannot choose but amaze him.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: If he be not amazed, he will be mocked; if he be amazed, he will every way be mocked.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: We'll betray him finely.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Against such lewdsters and their lechery, Those that betray them do no treachery.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: The hour draws on. To the oak, to the oak!

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Trib, trib, fairies. Come, and remember your parts. Be pold, I pray you, follow me into the pit, and when I give the watch-'ords, do as I pid you. Come, come; trib, trib.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: The Windsor bell hath struck twelve, the minute draws on. Now the hot-blooded gods assist me! Remember, Jove, thou wast a bull for thy Europa; love set on thy horns. O powerful love, that in some respects, makes a beast a man, in some other a man a beast! You were also, Jupiter, a swan for the love of Leda. O omnipotent love, how near the god drew to the complexion of a goose! A fault done first in the form of a beast; O Jove, a beastly fault! And then another fault in the semblance of a fowl; think on't, Jove, a foul fault! When gods have hot backs, what shall poor men do? For me, I am here a Windsor stag, and the fattest, I think, i' the forest. Send me a cool rut-time, Jove, or who can blame me to piss my tallow? Who comes here? My doe?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Sir John? Art thou there, my deer, my male deer?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: My doe with the black scut! Let the sky rain potatoes, let it thunder to the tune of "Greensleeves", hail kissing-comfits and snow eringoes; let there come a tempest of provocation, I will shelter me here.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Mistress Page is come with me, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Divide me like a bribed buck, each a haunch. I will keep my sides to myself, my shoulders for the fellow of this walk, and my horns I bequeath your husbands. Am I a woodman, ha? Speak I like Herne the hunter? Why, now is Cupid a child of conscience; he makes restitution. As I am a true spirit, welcome!

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Alas, what noise?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Heaven forgive our sins!

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: What should this be? MISTRESS FORD and MISTRESS PAGE. Away, away!

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: I think the devil will not have me damned, lest the oil that's in me should set hell on fire; he would never else cross me thus. Satyr, Pistol as Hobgoblin, Anne Page and children as Fairies, carrying tapers.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Fairies, black, grey, green, and white, You moonshine revellers and shades of night, You orphan heirs of fixed destiny, Attend your office and your quality. Crier Hobgoblin, make the fairy oyes.

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: Elves, list your names; silence, you airy toys! Cricket, to Windsor chimneys shalt thou leap, Where fires thou find'st unraked and hearths unswept, There pinch the maids as blue as bilberry. Our radiant queen hates sluts and sluttery.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: They are fairies, he that speaks to them shall die. I'll wink and couch. No man their works must eye.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Where's Bead? Go you, and where you find a maid That ere she sleep has thrice her prayers said, Rein up the organs of her fantasy; Sleep she as sound as careless infancy. But those as sleep and think not on their sins, Pinch them, arms, legs, backs, shoulders, sides, and shins.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: About, about! Search Windsor castle, elves, within and out. Strew good luck, oafs, on every sacred room, That it may stand till the perpetual doom In state as wholesome as in state 'tis fit, Worthy the owner and the owner it. The several chairs of order look you scour With juice of balm and every precious flower. Each fair instalment, coat, and several crest, With loyal blazon, evermore be blest! And nightly, meadow-fairies, look you sing, Like to the Garter's compass, in a ring. Th' expressure that it bears, green let it be, More fertile-fresh than all the field to see; And _Honi soit qui mal y pense_ write In em'rald tufts, flowers purple, blue and white, Like sapphire, pearl, and rich embroidery, Buckled below fair knighthood's bending knee. Fairies use flowers for their charactery. Away, disperse! But till 'tis one o'clock, Our dance of custom round about the oak Of Herne the hunter let us not forget.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Pray you, lock hand in hand, yourselves in order set; And twenty glow-worms shall our lanterns be, To guide our measure round about the tree. But stay, I smell a man of middle earth.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Heavens defend me from that Welsh fairy, lest he transform me to a piece of cheese!

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: Vile worm, thou wast o'erlooked even in thy birth.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: With trial-fire touch me his finger-end. If he be chaste, the flame will back descend And turn him to no pain; but if he start, It is the flesh of a corrupted heart.

dialogues.speaker: Pistol
dialogues.line: A trial, come.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Come, will this wood take fire?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: O, o, o!

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Quickly
dialogues.line: Corrupt, corrupt, and tainted in desire! About him, fairies, sing a scornful rhyme, And, as you trip, still pinch him to your time.

dialogues.speaker: Song
dialogues.line: Fie on sinful fantasy! Fie on lust and luxury! Lust is but a bloody fire, Kindled with unchaste desire, Fed in heart, whose flames aspire, As thoughts do blow them, higher and higher. Pinch him, fairies, mutually; Pinch him for his villainy. Pinch him and burn him and turn him about, Till candles and starlight and moonshine be out.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Nay, do not fly. I think we have watched you now. Will none but Herne the hunter serve your turn?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: I pray you, come, hold up the jest no higher.- Now, good Sir John, how like you Windsor wives? See you these, husband? Do not these fair yokes Become the forest better than the town?

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Now, sir, who's a cuckold now? Master Brook, Falstaff's a knave, a cuckoldly knave. Here are his horns, Master Brook. And, Master Brook, he hath enjoyed nothing of Ford's but his buck-basket, his cudgel, and twenty pounds of money, which must be paid to Master Brook. His horses are arrested for it, Master Brook.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Ford
dialogues.line: Sir John, we have had ill luck, we could never meet. I will never take you for my love again, but I will always count you my deer.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: I do begin to perceive that I am made an ass.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Ay, and an ox too. Both the proofs are extant.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: And these are not fairies? I was three or four times in the thought they were not fairies; and yet the guiltiness of my mind, the sudden surprise of my powers, drove the grossness of the foppery into a received belief, in despite of the teeth of all rhyme and reason, that they were fairies. See now how wit may be made a Jack-a-Lent when 'tis upon ill employment!

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Sir John Falstaff, serve Got, and leave your desires, and fairies will not pinse you.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Well said, fairy Hugh.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: And leave you your jealousies too, I pray you.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: I will never mistrust my wife again, till thou art able to woo her in good English.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Have I laid my brain in the sun, and dried it, that it wants matter to prevent so gross o'erreaching as this? Am I ridden with a Welsh goat too? Shall I have a cox-comb of frieze? 'Tis time I were choked with a piece of toasted cheese.

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: Seese is not good to give putter. Your belly is all putter.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: "Seese" and "putter"? Have I lived to stand at the taunt of one that makes fritters of English? This is enough to be the decay of lust and late-walking through the realm.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Why, Sir John, do you think, though we would have thrust virtue out of our hearts by the head and shoulders, and have given ourselves without scruple to hell, that ever the devil could have made you our delight?

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: What, a hodge-pudding? A bag of flax?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: A puffed man?

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Old, cold, withered, and of intolerable entrails?

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: And one that is as slanderous as Satan?

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: And as poor as Job?

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: And as wicked as his wife?

dialogues.speaker: Evans
dialogues.line: And given to fornications, and to taverns, and sack, and wine, and metheglins, and to drinkings and swearings and starings, pribbles and prabbles?

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: Well, I am your theme. You have the start of me. I am dejected, I am not able to answer the Welsh flannel. Ignorance itself is a plummet o'er me. Use me as you will.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, we'll bring you to Windsor to one Master Brook, that you have cozened of money, to whom you should have been a pander. Over and above that you have suffered, I think to repay that money will be a biting affliction.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Yet be cheerful, knight. Thou shalt eat a posset tonight at my house, where I will desire thee to laugh at my wife, that now laughs at thee. Tell her Master Slender hath married her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Doctors doubt that. If Anne Page be my daughter, she is, by this, Doctor Caius' wife.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Whoa, ho, ho, father Page!

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Son, how now! How now, son, have you dispatched?

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: Dispatched? I'll make the best in Gloucestershire know on't. Would I were hanged, la, else!

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Of what, son?

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: I came yonder at Eton to marry Mistress Anne Page, and she's a great lubberly boy. If it had not been i' the church, I would have swinged him, or he should have swinged me. If I did not think it had been Anne Page, would I might never stir! And 'tis a postmaster's boy.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Upon my life, then, you took the wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: What need you tell me that? I think so, when I took a boy for a girl. If I had been married to him, for all he was in woman's apparel, I would not have had him.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Why, this is your own folly. Did not I tell you how you should know my daughter by her garments?

dialogues.speaker: Slender
dialogues.line: I went to her in white and cried "mum", and she cried "budget", as Anne and I had appointed, and yet it was not Anne, but a postmaster's boy.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Good George, be not angry. I knew of your purpose, turned my daughter into green, and indeed she is now with the doctor at the deanery, and there married.

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Vere is Mistress Page? By gar, I am cozened, I ha' married _un garçon_, a boy; _un paysan_, by gar, a boy. It is not Anne Page. By gar, I am cozened.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Why, did you take her in green?

dialogues.speaker: Caius
dialogues.line: Ay, by gar, and 'tis a boy. By gar, I'll raise all Windsor.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: This is strange. Who hath got the right Anne?

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: My heart misgives me. Here comes Master Fenton.-How now, Master Fenton!

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Pardon, good father. Good my mother, pardon.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Now, mistress, how chance you went not with Master Slender?

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Why went you not with Master Doctor, maid?

dialogues.speaker: Fenton
dialogues.line: You do amaze her. Hear the truth of it. You would have married her most shamefully, Where there was no proportion held in love. The truth is, she and I, long since contracted, Are now so sure that nothing can dissolve us. Th' offence is holy that she hath committed, And this deceit loses the name of craft, Of disobedience, or unduteous title, Since therein she doth evitate and shun A thousand irreligious cursed hours, Which forced marriage would have brought upon her.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Stand not amazed, here is no remedy. In love, the heavens themselves do guide the state. Money buys lands, and wives are sold by fate.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: I am glad, though you have ta'en a special stand to strike at me, that your arrow hath glanced.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Well, what remedy? Fenton, heaven give thee joy! What cannot be eschewed must be embraced.

dialogues.speaker: Falstaff
dialogues.line: When night-dogs run, all sorts of deer are chased.

dialogues.speaker: Mistress Page
dialogues.line: Well, I will muse no further.-Master Fenton, Heaven give you many, many merry days! Good husband, let us every one go home, And laugh this sport o'er by a country fire, Sir John and all.

dialogues.speaker: Ford
dialogues.line: Let it be so, Sir John, To Master Brook you yet shall hold your word, For he tonight shall lie with Mistress Ford.
